column10:
Just a phenomena of its time. Holds up ..fine in terms of its content - some is definitely of the early 2000s tolerance, but who cares? It's nostalgia, and it's just good fun. Yes, this is the one where you can oh, so controversially sleep with a hooker, then kill her and take back the money. And yes, you can also play for hours on end saving people around town as ambulance crew. It's like choose your own adventure, right?
Really, though, the gunplay surprisingly does hold up, and remains fun. The driving has been some of the greatest open-world vehicle fun you can have.
The feel of each atmosphere, each city is unique and memorable. Even the B-tier missions are fun, eventful and have fully voiced, fantastic character work. The soundtracks of each radio station only emphasise the point already made 5 times over. Again, it's the characters and the ambiance, not necessarily the incredible story or morals discussed here.

You just have fun. You load up this game and you have chaotic, old-school, good-hearted fun. It is full of violence, but hey, it's a video game - you're supposed to load off in these things, so as not to do similar in real-life situations. Or whatever excuse you wanna employ.

Best GTA game ever made....fight me. Vice City was good and GTA III but Niko Bellic for me had zero charisma and I have to say GTA IV has to be the most depressing and miserable of the collection not to mention a huge let down as they removed all the cool side quests and discoverables, there is literally no reason to search Liberty City in IV as there is nothing to find, unlike San Andreas which is packed with content. You can run in any direction in SA and eventually hit a weapon pick up or a cash boosting mini game and to a lesser degree Vice City and GTA III were the same and thats why I prefer this and the pre GTA IV titles also the music and radio in this is the best of any of the games imho.
3 broke ground for what open world games could be, SA did it again with what GTA games could be.

Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas is a remarkable game in the series, arguably one of the best. It expands the series’ concept to encompass three entire cities, as well as the countryside between them. The gameplay is thrilling, packing in explosive set pieces and action-movie-like thrills while maintaining that fun, freeform GTA feel. The dialogue between characters is raw but convincing, with some big-name celebrities contributing their vocal talent

Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas continued the success of GTA: Vice City and is built on the same engine.

Set within the fictional state of San Andreas, the game follows Carl "CJ" Johnson, who returns home after his mother's murder and finds his old friends and family in disarray. Over the course of the game, he attempts to re-establish his old gang, clashes with corrupt authorities and powerful criminals, and gradually unravels the truth behind his mother's murder.

Sadly, this version of the game is no longer available on Steam, and you have to play it via the Definitive Edition.

𝗚𝗿𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗧𝗵𝗲𝗳𝘁 𝗔𝘂𝘁𝗼: 𝗦𝗮𝗻 𝗔𝗻𝗱𝗿𝗲𝗮𝘀 je ikonická hra, která se odehrává ve fiktivním státě San Andreas v roce 1992. Tato hra nabízí hráčům obrovský a propracovaný otevřený svět, který je plný dobrodružství a možností prozkoumávání. Hra zaujme hráče nejen svou rozsáhlou mapou, ale také skvělým příběhem a různorodými herními mechanismy.

Jedním z nejvýraznějších prvků hry je její příběh, který sleduje život hlavní postavy jménem Carl Johnson. Hráči se dostanou do světa gangů, korupce a intrik, což přináší napínavé mise a dramatické situace. Díky skvěle napsanému příběhu a vynikajícím postavám se hráči snadno vcítí do děje a prožívají s postavami jejich vzestupy a pády.

Dalším pozitivním prvkem hry je její rozmanitost. Hráči mají možnost provádět různé činnosti, jako je řízení aut, létání letadel, bojování ve streetových soubojích a dokonce i budování svalů nebo vztahů s ostatními postavami. Tato rozmanitost přispívá k hloubce a zábavě hry, jelikož hráči mají neustále nové výzvy a možnosti, které mohou prozkoumat.

Grafika a zvukový design hry také stojí za zmínku. I přes svůj věk si hra udržela kvalitní vizuální a zvukové efekty, které přispívají k vytvoření autentické atmosféry a prostředí.

Celkově lze říci, že Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas je skvělou hrou, která nabízí hráčům neuvěřitelně rozsáhlý a poutavý svět plný akce, dobrodružství a příběhů. S kvalitním příběhem, rozmanitými herními mechanismy a vynikající grafikou a zvukem je tato hra jedním z vrcholů herního průmyslu a rozhodně stojí za to ji vyzkoušet.

I used TJGM's "Ultimate Modding Guide" to setup this game. You should 100% do the same and also install GInput if you want to use a controller with correct button prompts. 

I also transferred it to my steam deck and it worked perfectly! Make sure and put this in your launch options on steam deck "WINEDLLOVERRIDES="vorbisFile,vorbisHooked,bass=n,b" %command%"

Oldie but goldie. Can't even remember when I last played this game. Probably on PS2 back in the day and now I decided to replay it on PC.

First things first, I immediately downloaded "GTA SA - The Improved Classic Modpack" to hopefully improve the gameplay a little bit. Because I did try to play this few year back without any mods and I do remember it being very buggy on PC. But the modpack did not fix everything, probably helped a ton in the background. So be prepared for various bugs and issues.

For example: cut-scenes getting stuck where the car is supposed to exit a garage (driving against a wall repeatably). Taking a picture with the camera crashes (you had to disable some picture saving thing from settings). Random crashes mid-mission/game (remember to go save the game).

But I mean, there's no point to "review" this game as there are hundreds, probably thousands of reviews of this game already. We know the game is good. Just remember, save the game often, there are no checkpoints and just because of the crashes. Enjoy the game while playing. Took me about 35h to finish the game with all tags, oysters and horseshoes. Car export also finished. Bunch of gambling of course.

[h1]Nostalgia-Fueled Masterpiece That Withstands Time[/h1]

Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas stands as a testament to gaming brilliance, drawing players into the bustling streets of Los Santos, San Fierro, and Las Venturas. The engaging narrative follows CJ's journey, complete with twists, turns, and unforgettable characters. The sprawling open world invites exploration, and the diverse missions showcase Rockstar Games' storytelling prowess.

The customization options elevate the experience, allowing players to tailor CJ's appearance and even modify vehicles. The soundtrack, featuring tracks from the '90s, seamlessly complements the atmosphere, enhancing the immersion in this virtual world.

However, the game's aging graphics, a relic of its 2004 release, might be a stumbling block for those accustomed to modern visual standards. The controls, while functional, can feel a bit cumbersome, especially during intense moments, occasionally leading to frustrating encounters.

The inconsistent AI behavior in certain missions and limitations in interactivity are noticeable but, in the grand scheme, don't significantly detract from the overall experience. San Andreas' depth and complexity may present a steep learning curve for newcomers, but it's a journey well worth taking.

For seasoned players, San Andreas is a nostalgic voyage to a bygone era of gaming. For newcomers, it's a chance to explore the roots of the open-world genre, forgiving its quirks in favor of the unparalleled sense of freedom it offers. Despite its imperfections, GTA: San Andreas remains an enduring masterpiece that transcends time, delivering a gaming experience that's as captivating today as it was nearly two decades ago.

Years ago, when I was little I played this game non-stop on my crappy PC, using every cheat code I wrote down in my notebook and exploring every little corner of the map and finding every little secret. I loved this game but sadly, I never really got to finish it since one of the cheat codes made some missions impossible to complete, effectively corrupting my save file. Little me did not know that but when I stumbled upon a post back in 2018 I found this out and it was a total shock! Later down the line I purchased myself a copy on steam and got to finish the game and story once and for all. I loved it! The game is just as I remember, a masterpiece.
Thank you Rockstar.

Unless I'm mistaken, GTA: San Andreas is the last game utilizing its engine. It also still feels and plays like a game and less like real life, which is where the following GTA games were going. Police bribes for slowly reducing wanted level, vigilante missions for increasing body armor strength, firefighter missions to make you completely fireproof and more.
It may not look as good as the following games but it's still fun to play twenty years after its release, and the music is just as good as ever.

I highly recommend this game since 2004, but now its a must have because it seems this version is unavailable. 

I applied the Definitive Edition patch and made my control scheme on the steam input thing. I made the controls to be like OG Xbox with some changes to match the modern era. 
Here is the link:
steam://controllerconfig/12120/3131288755

I then went to my nividia control panel changed max frame rate to 60 and turned vertical sync on for the San Andreas EXE. Then within the game Draw distance at max, Frame Limiter off, Widescreen on, visual fx Very high, MIP mapping on, Anti aliasing 8X, and resolution 3840 x 2160 x 32.

Im playing in 4k 60fps no glitches. Best time im ever having.

Legendary Rockstar masterpiece. 

Those who lived during this era knew what it was like to get your hands on a copy of San Andreas, especially if you were underage. 

This game had it all - 90s hood gangster theme, killer soundtrack, hot coffee controversy, hype, endless fun, guns, cars, hookers, drugs, story, characters, the freedom to do whatever you want in 3 large areas and packed to the brim with content. It's no question that this entry is beloved by so many.

Now that i'm older and returning to classics, i can't believe they removed this version but come here listen to Uncle Sweet. Do yourself a favor, if you can, get your hands on this copy through other means.... 💿🔑 or 🏴‍☠️, the choice is yours. 

Whatever you do, do not give your money to Rockstar and buy that dogsh1t version of San Andreas called the "Definitive Edition". That version is ass and we both know it, so don't do it. 

The modding community comes clutch, just follow some guides and youtube vids, patch it with easy fixes and mod it to your hearts content. You can even add in Hot Coffee mod for a true authentic experience :)
I WANT THEM BACK ROCKSTAR
Can never go wrong with a classic.

Where to even start? This game provides an amazingly expansive open world with almost limitless freedom. The main story is long enough, but doesn't overstay its welcome. Apart from the main story, the game offers a wide variety of side content, none of which feels boring or repetitive, barring some of the collectibles. It features a large ammount of hidden content and you always feel like you're discovering something new. The cast is top notch, with very memorable charactes. The story is well written, but it does diverge from it's initial focus on gang violence and reverts to a more classical GTA experience at a certain point. It does, however, return to it's roots and closes it out with a satisfactory ending. Overall, I'd say the story is more focused on the protagonist's personal journey and is executed extremelly well. The map is very large and diverse, successfully making each part feel alive and different. The gameplay is fun but slightly dated. The vehicle handling is superb, but the combat leaves a bit to be desired. The weapon variety is commendable, however, the lack of a proper cover system does create issues. Overall, this is a must play game that is greatly recommended.

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

The new and experimental mechanics were really fun and i'm saddened rockstar scrapped a lot of them when moving to the HD games (hopefully GTA 6 can maybe add and improve on some of these features), but thats just further reason to give this game a try. What a fucking catastrophe of a game, not only the game itself but rockstars choices with it

-You lose all your weapons when you die
-First 2 hours of the game is bullshit and all the missions are bullshit and nearly impossible to complete because of garbage mission and game design
-Combat is inconsistent as fuck, sometimes your bullets dont register or the enemy headshots you and kills you in 3 hits
-CJ's starting health is abysmal and a fly farting in his direction will kill him.
-You just die randomly at times like when climbing over a fucking fence
-At random, you will get shot at by all of the rival gang members, even when only being in their turf for 5 seconds.
-NPCs become beserk when you accidentally scrape their car, so then their car gains massive speed and weight buffs and they will constantly chase you and ram you off the road.
-No checkpoints, so that combined with you lose all your weapons when you die leads to losing massive progress and starting at square one with almost no way to get weapons other than a shitty ass pistol within the first 2 hours of the game
-Depending on the mission, if you fail, you will be stranded in the middle of nowhere with no form of transportation.
-You either must play with 20 FPS, or uncapped FPS, there is no in-between. And uncapped FPS leads to massive issues with gameplay and the game engine.
-Some missions just dont work like the Cesar Vialpando mission being near impossible to complete since the buttons for the mini-game are switched, reversed and just dont register sometimes.
-You can no longer buy the original game on the steam store anymore, you must buy the definitive edition.

Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas is not the perfect game but it is iconic and defiantly worth the try ill start with getting the bad parts out of the way. The flying in this game is terrible, the map is cluttered the story has some points that make zero sense and some of it seems forced to drive the plot forward. However this game was insanely fun and it was a long experience filled with chainsaws, mini guns and jet packs CJ is an amazing main character funny and relatable at times while also confusing sometimes its hard to understand why CJ does half the things he does. The mini games are not as fun there are a few forced DDR style mini games at the start of the game but you only have to do it twice, there is also a part where you need to upgrade your lung capacity by swimming underwater to progress through the next mission and grinding out skills is not what i want from a GTA game but good out weighs the bad and i do believe this game is worth giving a try.

[b] INT. LIVING ROOM - DAY

The cast of Friends, including Buffy and the Scooby Gang, sit on the couch. CJ from GTA San Andreas hands out game controllers. The door opens, and the MYSTERY INC. GANG (Scooby-Doo, Shaggy, Fred, Daphne, and Velma) enters.

ROSS:
(holding a controller) Okay, so what's the deal with this game? Are we saving the world or just stealing cars?

BUFFY:
Actually, it's a bit of both. We're in the gangsta world of San Andreas, where CJ here is trying to save his family and take over the streets.

MONICA:
Gangsta? Like hip-hop gangsta or "I just stole your pizza" gangsta?

CJ:
Both, homie. Grove Street life, ya know?

XANDER:
So, it's like a combination of "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air" and "Breaking Bad"?

JOEY:
Whoa, breaking bad? Like, are we cooking meth in the game?

WILLOW:
No, Joey, it's more about drive-bys than drive-throughs.

(They all start playing, laughter and chaos ensuing as they navigate the game world. The MYSTERY INC. GANG looks on, confused.)

SHAGGY:
Like, Scoob, did we take a wrong turn at Albuquerque?

FRED:
This doesn't look like any mystery we've solved before.

VELMA:
And who are these people? "Scooby Gang"? What kind of name is that?

BUFFY:
Hey, we've been the "Scooby Gang" way before you guys were solving mysteries.

SHAGGY:
Zoinks! We've got some impostors.

ROSS:
No, no, guys, we're the original Scooby Gang. We even have a Phoebe Buffay the Vampire Slayer.

PHOEBE:
Yeah, I slay vampires with my guitar and the power of weirdness.

SCOOBY-DOO:
Rikes! Rooby-Rooby-Roo, what's going on here?

DAPHNE:
I think we've entered a crossover episode.

MONICA:
(looking at Mystery Inc.) Are you guys from "Friends" too?

VELMA:
(confused) No, we're from "Scooby-Doo." But who are you people?

(The chaos continues as they all try to explain their respective worlds to each other. Matthew Perry, as Chandler, appears in the game as a virtual character.)

CHANDLER:
Could this game BE any more chaotic?

EVERYONE:
(laughs)

ROSS:
Man, we miss you, Chandler.

BUFFY:
Yeah, rest in peace, Matthew Perry. You brought so much joy and sarcasm into our lives.

MONICA:
Let's dedicate this virtual mayhem to Chandler!

(They continue playing, reminiscing and making in-game tributes to the late Matthew Perry.)

WILLOW:
Okay, can we talk about this game? The open-world concept is revolutionary! I mean, I just stole a plane, and now I'm flying over Los Santos. ✈️

FRED:
That's nothing. I found a mystery van in the game, and now we're cruising in style. 🚐

BUFFY:
And the story? It's like a mix of "The Sopranos" and "Buffy the Vampire Slayer." CJ is on a quest for revenge and family, just like me. 🔪🧛‍♀️

DAPHNE:
Oh, I love a good revenge story. It's so mysterious. 🕵️‍♀️

(The MYSTERY INC. GANG looks at Daphne, confused.)

VELMA:
And what about the music? It's like a blast from the past. 🎵

JOEY:
Yeah, totally. I got in a car, and "Don't Stop Believin'" by Journey started playing. It was like a scene from a classic rock opera. 🎸🎤

SCOOBY-DOO:
Rooby-Rooby-Roo, did someone say "classic rock"? 🤘

XANDER:
And the humor in this game? It's Chandler-level sarcastic. 😂

PHOEBE:
Chandler would have loved this game. I can feel his sarcasm resonating through the pixels. 😎

SHAGGY:
Like, speaking of pixels, are we sure this is real life or just a game? 🎮

BUFFY:
We're all in this together, whether it's real or virtual. Let's make it a night to remember. 🌟

(They all continue playing, discussing the game, sharing laughs, and creating a crossover experience that transcends the boundaries of their respective worlds. The laughter echoes through the room, a tribute to the late Matthew Perry and the joy he brought to millions.)

"From those early missions in the neighbourhoods of Los Santos, San Andreas widens the scope to draw in the rest of that city, then keeps going. Vast tracts of countryside, hills and forests surround the looming bulk of Mount Chiliad. Then comes San Fierro, the city by the bay, and deeper still into the game you can head to Las Venturas, the gambling mecca in the desert. Each is its own place, with its own feel. And that's crucial. These are places that you can feel, more than just rearranged assets or a new gameplay stage. The devil is in the details, and Rockstar's intricate web makes these cities feel lived in, as if they were always there, not just conjured up from ones and zeroes stored on a disc." - Eurogamer, 2012

Played this as a first-timer using my deck on my work breaks and it's genuinely my favourite GTA game, pushing aside the temperamental combat, the vehicle mechanics and core concepts from this game are essentially the same as all of the other GTA games, including the newer ones.

EASILY my favourite map and story from any GTA game, and my favourite to fuck around and drive in. If you can look past the mushy textures (playing on the steam deck though, the game doesn't actually look too bad), and as mentioned, the dated combat mechanics, then the rest of the game has aged like fine wine.

With all of this being said it looks like the game is no longer on the steam store, I have played the definitive edition before and it comes with it's benefits, such as graphical upgrades and quality of life updates (I enjoyed my time playing it personally), but it has also somehow managed to miss out some of the details from the original and it just doesn't have the same feeling to it.

For the most part, it's the game I remember. It's awesome, though it's age does show. 

I used to play this on PS2, and I feel like a few things are quite different on the PC port. Timers, for instance. Things disappear way too quickly. If a Balla drops a gun, you better haul ass to go get it or it's gone. Then again, if you remember some of the gun spawns or go for the tags, it really doesn't matter. 
Another timer that seems absurdly fast is the girlfriend one. Denise seems to call every day and when you don't go out, that bar drops fast, man. Again though, not sure it matters. I can never remember what you get from her, so it can't be that great.

What does matter though, is that the physics get quirky on higher frame-rates. I think it's different depending on the PC, but when I let it go above 60, cars start auto-braking when I let go of gas. It may affect the lowrider and dance minigames as well, but my timing could just be terrible. On the lowrider one, it seems that for some people, like me, the vertical directions are reversed. Up is down, down is up. Do if you see a lot of "Bads" that feel like they shouldn't be, try swapping those keybinds.

And the AI... god, the AI... But that was always terrible. You don't need em anyway. Just grab yourself an AK and make Los Santos green again!

So yeah, couple of quirks. Still one of the best games I've ever played, though. Enjoying every second of it again... when I'm not dealing with those quirks lol

edit: just leave the frame limiter on. Swimming doesn't work with it off either. Who knows what else breaks. Shame, but it is a 20 year old game.

Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas' is a timeless epic in the gaming world! Venturing through the sprawling, detailed landscapes of Los Santos, San Fierro, and Las Venturas feels like stepping into a living, breathing universe. The narrative is masterfully woven, with characters that remain iconic to this day. Rockstar didn't just create a game; they crafted an entire era, capturing the essence of '90s culture while providing limitless freedom to the player. The soundtrack alone is a journey through time, accompanying you as you embark on unforgettable adventures. A cornerstone of gaming history, 'San Andreas' is a monumental achievement that set the gold standard for open-world games. An unequivocal 10/10 – pure gaming nirvana!

[h3] Has the world moved on from GTA: San Andreas? [/h3]

I was 9 years old when San Andreas became a media storm, with game’s name being whispered among concerned parents as a threat they should protect their children from. My mum bought into the paranoia. One evening I was suspiciously questioned by her: “What do you know about San Andreas?” Sensing a potential trap, I played dumb to bring out her own thoughts and opinions first. This introduced a new era of parental awareness around video games and, in my mind, San Andreas represents one of the last victims of mature content controversy from a now bygone era.

Nearly 20 years on, violent titles no longer bat an eye. Their ubiquity, social acceptance and their transition to digital storefronts meant such games couldn’t be hidden behind shop counters. San Andreas isn’t just a time capsule for controversy, but also cutting edge graphics, genre foundations and pop culture references. Going into San Andreas, I wondered if such an aggressively 2004 game would still play well. It also represented the first time I’ve been able to play it fully, at my own leisure. Take that, mum.

San Andreas is a story-focused game and there are nearly 100 levels spanning around 25 hours to complete. You play as Carl Johnson, and each chapter is connected to a different part of the city, swapping up the environments and themes to keep the game fresh. The first chapter is mostly gangbanging around Los Santos as you represent Grove Street, affectionately termed ‘The Grove’. Story-wise, this chapter introduces the game’s most iconic characters such as the Eazy-E tribute Ryder, and wanna-be kingpin Smoke. 

OG Loc is a standout character: a studio gangster who you help cheat his way into the rap game. Immediately his missions are filled with standout lines, like when he’s released from jail:

[i] “Man, I ain’t free! My parole officer lined me up with a job” [/i]
[i] “Motherfucker always trying to keep a player down” [/i]

His wildcard energy matched with deep insecurity over his street credentials, and you’re responsible for stealing rhyme books for him while Grove Street pump money into releasing his debut album ‘Str8 From Tha Streetz (and ode to Eazy-E’s double LP ‘Str8 Off Tha Streetz of Muthaphukkin Compton’) and his clothing line. 

While San Andreas social commentary is mostly satire, the unrestrained Catalina provides a surprisingly poignant moment of feminism, albeit in the middle of a crime spree, when she shouts:

[i] "If we're passionate, [men] say we're crazy, if we're upset, you say we're hysterical, we sleep with men, we're sluts, if we don't put out we're frigid bitches." [/i]

The rest of the San Andreas politics isn’t usually played so sincerely. Most crime bosses in SA are insecure, impulsive and hedonistic. However, I really enjoyed the Chinese Triad leader Woozie who challenges these expectations. Woozie is calm, relaxed and humbled by his blindness. He performs his role as a criminal boss with the least amount of bloodshed, is rarely angry, and always treats people with dignity and respect, including himself. I loved the occasional glimpses into his past times, which instead of involving hookers and violence, include mini golf and video-games, leading to a great exchange when he admits his blindness to Carl. 

[i] Carl: “Uh, one last thing. You do know that I'm black, right? And not Chinese.” [/i]
[i] Woozie: “I'm blind, Carl, not stupid.” [/i]

Woozie’s character teaches CJ to see past a person’s disability and instead value them for their intelligence and skill. In another instance, one of Woozie’s henchmen puts down two casino chips in front of him:

[i] Woozie : One's a fake. [/i]
[i] Carl Johnson : That's amazing. You didn't even touch them. [/i]
[i] Woozie : No. I just took a guess. Why else would he come in with two chips and sound so worried? [/i]

The first chapter of San Andreas is filled with admittedly funny stereotypes running the show, yet it feels the wittiest in the later chapters when it purposefully subverts expectations for its jokes. It doesn’t stop a car outlet being named “Wang Cars”, but the balance of juvenile and witty stops San Andreas from feeling pretentious.

As you might expect, there is jank. San Andreas vehicles drive horribly on KB+M (a curse for playing GTA on such an uncool platform) and the shooting features the worst targeting system you’ve ever experienced on a controller. By the second on-foot combat mission, ‘Sweet’s Girl’, I was already struggling to line up my character, select a weapon, lock on, and fire: all to kill a single enemy. To do a driveby, you have to press RT + B + A simultaneously while also steering your car - it’s hell. Eventually I settled into a 360 controller for driving, for the benefits of analog, while switching to KB+M for manual shooting sections, which felt much quicker to aim and shoot.

However, the characters and storylines carry GTA San Andreas. While the driving is merely okay, and the combat often downright bad, the memorable cast and humour gives the game a huge boost of heart and soul. Spending 25 hours with these characters is fun, and I haven’t even mentioned the Samuel L Jackson voiced Officer Tenpenny, who virtually reprises his role from Pulp Fiction. Make to use the mod GTA Classic Enhanced to fix some issues and restore 21 licensed music tracks, and this game is still worth playing now.

The Ambitious One.

San Andreas looked at all the freedom in GTA 3 and Vice City and gave us even more. A massive game, even to today's standards, stretching across 3 cities in a state based on both California and Nevada, and truly reaching a point of bizarre and grandiose with missions that GTA later took with the PSP games, GTA 5, and even Saints Row tried to copy before going way off the deep end. 

CJ is customsable beyond belief, with you being able to choose his clothes, hairstyles, give him tattoos, and even affecting his body weight and muscle mass. This GTA is easily the closest the franchise came to making an RPG, with skill levelling in operating vehicles and weapons. The freedom is unmatched and for the GTA with the longest storyline (spanning exactly 100 missions with a speedrun world record as high as 3 hours), it's also got the most that can be done post game - CJ can capture all the turf in Los Santos, buy out all of the many properties in the game, can customise and tune out his cars (later expanded upon in GTA 5), and rampages and 6-Star chases feel the most fun and satisfying in this GTA - start a run in Los Santos and see how quickly, or IF, you can make it to San Fierro and then to Las Venturas. It's a blast.

The game does have some minor moot points - the graphics despite this being the best looking base 3D era GTA still haven't aged particularly well and the trademark compressed voices outside of cutscenes also stick out a lot more than they used to. Some missions are just ridiculously difficult and despite the RPG stat system being welcomed, some missions are gated behind certain conditions relating to it which can become annoying. 

But all in all, this is the GTA that really showed that Rockstar are capable of masterpieces. Probably one of the biggest injustices in video game review journalism was this getting 9.9 from IGN and not 10. It's not my personal favourite GTA, but it's damn near a masterpiece that really pushed the limits of what the PS2, and any console or even PC games, could do at the time. Wonderful game that I'd recommend to anyone.

Why yes I am reviewing a game that's now pulled from stores! What's T2 going to do to me now? I can make fun of this game all I want because I can!

San Andreas has become a martyr of a game in the modern age, a hitching post for a generation of neo-boomers to sit back and talk about the good ol' days. Long before GTA V's painfully ironic humor, and before Rockstar realized the absolute money printer that was GTA:O, when they were making "new" games. The send off to the ol' 3D engine of the previous GTA games, SA was supposed to be bigger, better, shinier, more polished and definitely not an almost overly massive even for the time project that had to be cut back SEVERAL times in development.

You play as CJ Johnson, a banger who returns home from Liberty City to find his mom is dead, his hood has gone wild and his crew is either almost dead, turning state's evidence or being murdered by the Ballas. It's up to you to somehow figure out what's going down in Los Santos and don't question how this also involves you going to San Fierro, beating up Charlie Murphy and MC Eiht, then going to Las Venturas and robbing a casino and THEN going back to shoot Sam Jackson in the face. Intercut with the Legally Mandated amount of gimmick missions. And gaps in the radio from the original OST that was pulled because the license ran out.

No I'm not mad that Bounce FM is now decimated. Not at all.

San Andreas reminds me of something like Saints Row: The Third. It's a cumulative game, the coagulation of 2-4 different game's worth of content, ideas and gimmicks sandwiched between two oversized slabs of Texas Toast. It is, without question, very long and filled with so many oddball ideas that don't realistically matter. What does the gym give you? Why do you have to actually go and eat food? Is it worth making yourself fat or doing the low rider races? No one knows, nor do they question the plot bouncing around SoCal like a manic pixie dream girl operating with a corporate credit card. 

This game is bad in my eyes, it's janky, its plot is overly weird and bounces around the place. But in comparison to what's happened to both it and GTA, I love it. Every dumb idea in this game comes not from some corporate idea of making sure there's "everything" possible in it, it comes from a bunch of dumbasses in England thinking what'd be cool to render in their game engine. It's honest jank, intentional and stupid. And I miss that.

What can you really say that isn't immediately obvious to anyone who hasn't lived under a rock for the past decade? This is easily one of, if not THE, best GTA game ever made.

You play as Carl Johnson, an ex-gangster who returns to his roots after the death of a relative. Finding the city he grew up in covered in gang warfare and his family fractured, Carl sticks around to help turn things around, but is caught up in the whims of corrupt police officers.

Initially a satiric take on the gang warfare rife in LA in the 90s, San Andreas develops into much more than this as you progress through the main storyline. There are additional activities to take part in which add to  the RPG-style gameplay, such as betting, shooting ranges, HGV deliveries and a selection of places to eat and girls to date. Everywhere you go there is something to discover.

If you haven't played this game yet, play it now. If you have played this game before, play it again.

Gangsta simulator

Ah, GTA San Andreas, where do I even begin? This game is a certified hood classic that takes me back to the glorious mid-2000s. So, let's cruise down memory lane and talk about why this game is an absolute gem.

[h1]Replayability for Days:[/h1]

Now, when it comes to replayability, San Andreas is off the charts. I mean, seriously, you can sink hundreds of hours into this bad boy and still find new things to do. Whether you're wreaking havoc in Los Santos or just cruising around on your BMX, there's always something to keep you entertained.

[h1]Unique Mechanics Galore:[/h1]

But what sets San Andreas apart from the newer GTA games are the mechanics. We're talking gang turf warfare, mini arcade games, and the ability to build up your character's body and stats like it's an RPG. It's a smorgasbord of gameplay features that you won't find in other GTA titles, and it's a blast to explore them all.

[h1]A Timeless Story:[/h1]

And let's not forget about the story. It's not just a game; it's a cinematic experience. The tale of CJ and his journey through the mean streets of San Andreas is nothing short of legendary. Looking at it now, I can't help but think it would make an excellent movie on its own. It's got drama, action, humor, and a whole lot of heart.

In conclusion, GTA San Andreas is a bona fide classic that still holds up to this day. It's a nostalgia trip, a sandbox playground, and a gripping story all rolled into one. If you haven't experienced the glory of San Andreas, you're missing out. So grab a green bandana, hop in a lowrider, and get ready to take on the mean streets of Los Santos once more. Grove Street for life!

While playing this game it reminded me of an event that occurred 8 years ago:

One time I was in a Burger King parking lot hitting some Reggie stuff. Sadly though my dealer had spiked it with LSD so when I went inside the Burger King I was in a different world. Unfortunately, I had Del Taco that morning for breakfast so I rushed to the bathroom. I still had a little bit of control at this point so I sat on the toilet and I pulled out my iPhone 5. While hitting the Reggie stuff in my Civic I was playing GTA San Andreas on my phone. Considering I was delirious at this point I just started playing it on the toilet. I was moving CJ around in the game and I came across a symbol. The symbol was a green Grove Street Graffiti tag. I gazed at it for like 5 minutes. I then stood up and then extruded a log and smeared it on the wall of the Burger King bathroom. The only reason why I probably continued was because I had the Del Taco that morning, so it was kind of green so I was sort of tagging the bathroom (For Grove Street). After I finished representing Grove Street I built up the courage to leave the bathroom. Considering I was high as a cloud I didn't consider pulling up my pants so I was pretty much Gone with the Wind. The manager was brooming in the dining area and so he started chasing me with the Broom when I ran into the dining area. However, I was partially immobile due to my having my pants hinder my traversal capabilities. I eventually escaped the Burger King with the manager chasing me and I entered my car still with my pants down. I somehow got home I rushed to my bed and I passed out. I was in a 36-hour coma, so a large amount of bacterial growth occurred during my slumber. So, unfortunately, I got a staph infection and needed to go to the hospital. The doctors cleaned me and fix me all up though. Sadly, it ended up costing me $38,000 for all of the medical expenses. I have permanent skin damage in that area and I learned a valuable lesson. Don't hit Reggie stuff from a dealer that looks like Ryder.

One of the greatest of all time. It has been 14 years since it's first release on PS2 and it is still one of the games that I enjoy most. Content-wise, San Andreas is the most filled in the series. There are tons of stuff to do and these activities are high on replayability even today thanks to the controls and dynamics that still feel fresh enough. 

The game also contains the best supporting cast in the whole series. So many dynamic characters. Wu Zi Mu, The Truth, Tenpenny, Cesar, Mike Toreno; each of them has a uniqueness that you will not see in any other game. Combine it with a decent enough rise and revenge story and here you have a strong immersion that will carry you through tons of missions and three cities.

Besides, when it comes to the radio stations San Andreas is the only one in the series that I find almost all the stations nice. Some of them are better than others for sure (like K-DST, K-Rose, Radio Los Santos and Radio X), yet every station has some awesome tracks. That is sadly not a case for other GTA games, at least for my liking.

Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas remains a timeless masterpiece that continues to define what an open-world game can be. Its engrossing narrative, diverse gameplay, and immersive world make it an unforgettable experience that has withstood the test of time. Whether you're a fan of action-packed missions or simply want to explore a meticulously crafted virtual world, GTA San Andreas offers an unrivaled adventure that remains as thrilling today as it was upon its release.

What Rockstar made in this game was lightning in a bottle than has never really been replicated 1:1. They've still made masterpieces since, but never like this one.

Don't let the few spare hours on this Steam copy fool you. I've poured hundreds of hours into the single-player, and thousands into the free mod "San Andreas Multiplayer". Over this time you really get to learn the game engine's intricacies over that time, such as the zones that limit vehicle speeds (Gant Bridge/The Strip), how to increase motorcycle speed, and the joys of flying a WWII plane upside down, for dogfighting or for aerial stunts.

The story is a love letter to 80s and 90s crime dramas, a stern acknowledgement of the crack epidemic and 1992 LA riots, and of course Rockstar's penchant for satirizing American consumerism.

CJ and friends go from the hood to the hills, with a lot of obstacles and crazy moments in between. The total story should run about 30 hours long. The concept of family and gang culture is well rooted, so well rooted in fact that the rival gangs become hostile if you're spotted on their turf wearing gang colors.

And customization of Carl is RPG-level. Everything from the hats and sunglasses, to the individual pieces of clothing, sex appeal, driving/flying abilities, weapon mastery, fat and stamina levels (which influence movement animations, how high you can jump, and whether you can begin certain missions). Eating at restaurants, working out at the gym, and going to the driving/shooting range all influence their respective stat values.


It is truly amazing how much depth they put into it. So much, in fact, that I think GTA IV and later games were right to scale it down. When I play single player San Andreas, I have to turn on the "Never Hungry" cheat, because I would never like to enter the fast food restaurants unless I truly wanted to.

But anyway - besides the main story, there's tons more to do. You had food delivery missions, gang wars, dating, triathlon races, gambling games, arcade games. But that's not all - you also had the police missions, ambulance missions, basketball, lowrider missions, and more.

From the rooftops and secret areas of Chinatown/Carlton Heights, to the stunningly accurate depictions of Las Vegas metro, intricate neighborhood dwellings of East Los Santos, Rockstar really took their time in crafting an SF-LA-LV experience all could appreciate.

On consoles, the two player mode was great, allowing tag-team gameplay that had you and a friend become a wrecking ball of destruction.

Definitely give this game a try. It's forgivable if you can only acquire the Unreal Engine Remastered Version, but the Renderware original has the unique charm and flying physics the remaster lacks.

I can't exactly say how many hours I put into this game. To me it's just the G.O.A.T. of every single video game out there. I remember the times when I played this on my Playstation 2. Those where great times.

To me it's even better than GTA 5, cuz GTA San Andreas has three big cities: Los Santos (Los Angeles), San Fierro (San Francisco) and Las Venturas (Las Vegas) unlike GTA 5, which has only one major city (Los Santos) and the rest is very rural with a few small villages & settlements.

Another pro-GTA San Andreas reason is building interiors. You can enter nightclubs, bars, casinos, fast food restaurants and so on. In GTA 5 most buildings are inaccessible, which is pretty sad.

And don't forget that in GTA San Andreas you can actually build your muscles and make out the result, unlike in GTA V and improve your endurance in the gym.

Another reason, why I prefer GTA San Andreas is, because San Andreas offers a wide range of side missions like boxing, BMX and NRG-500 challenges, courier trips, lowrider challenges, truck missions, quarry missions and arena challenges, which I've missed in the most recent GTA release.

Eventually everyone has his own opinion about what he/she prefers, but I think it's not all about graphics each time, instead the gameplay and experience matters more, at least to me. 

It just has a bigger variety than GTA 5 and more opportunities to do things and mess around in general and also allows random incidents like shootings between the police and gangs/criminals, communications between pedestrians themselves and between them and the player to happen.

Ah, Grand Theft Auto San Andreas... the legendary game that defined the PS2/Xbox era. It's a pity that Rockstar retired it from the store when Definitive Edition came out. Still, if you have this game in your library, I recommend it to you.

Compared to the killing machine Claude and the criminal Tommy, we play as a amateur gangster named CJ, who traveled back home to Los Santos (Los Angeles). With the help of his hood fellas, CJ will make his gang Grove Street great again. I consider it an excellent story. 

Luckily, gameplay aged better than Vice City's one. Now you can carry more weapons, drive better and increase stats such as being strong, having stamina... and of course, swimming. The only two things I hate from the game is the manual save every time and how primitive are the driving controls. Still, it aged better than Vice City.

I can't blame how the game looks, since it's a 2004 game, but remember that same year we got Half Life 2, which almost 20 years later it aged like fine wine compared to the cartoon style of San Andreas. The recreation of Los Angeles in the game is well done tho.

The sound in the Grand Theft Auto games never fails, and San Andreas is no exception. Not only the voice acting is good, but the music selected for the game is the best, truly the greatest music of the 90's.

Rockstar retired the game from Steam in order to let Definitive Edition replace the originals, so if you want to buy it, sorry. You can't.

As someone who played the game almost 20 years after its release, I can understand why many people consider it the best of the saga

Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas is a true gaming masterpiece that has stood the test of time. From the moment I stepped foot into the sprawling state of San Andreas, I was transported to an immersive world filled with endless possibilities, captivating stories, and unforgettable characters.

One of the most impressive aspects of San Andreas is the sheer scale of its open-world environment. From the bustling streets of Los Santos to the rural countryside and the vibrant city of San Fierro, the game offers an incredible variety of locations to explore. The attention to detail is astonishing, with every street corner, building, and landmark adding to the authenticity and immersion of the experience.

The narrative of San Andreas is a tour de force, weaving a complex and engaging tale of loyalty, betrayal, and personal growth. The protagonist, Carl "CJ" Johnson, is a deeply relatable and memorable character, and his journey through the criminal underworld is filled with dramatic twists and turns. The game's storyline is supported by a diverse cast of well-developed characters, each with their own unique personalities and motivations, creating a rich tapestry of narratives that keeps you invested from start to finish.

San Andreas offers an unparalleled level of freedom and player agency. Whether you want to follow the main story missions, engage in side activities, or simply roam the world at your leisure, the game grants you the freedom to do so. From hijacking cars, participating in thrilling shootouts, or engaging in high-speed chases, the gameplay is action-packed and exhilarating. The inclusion of RPG-like elements, such as customizable character attributes and the ability to build CJ's physical capabilities through exercise and training, adds a layer of depth and personalization to the experience.

The soundtrack of San Andreas is an absolute triumph. From the iconic radio stations playing a wide range of genres, including hip-hop, rock, and reggae, to the original score that perfectly complements the gameplay and atmosphere, the music adds an incredible level of immersion and nostalgia. The sound design, voice acting, and dialogue are all top-notch, further enhancing the overall quality of the game.

San Andreas also boasts an impressive array of side activities and mini-games. Whether it's participating in street races, gambling at casinos, engaging in gang wars, or simply exploring hidden secrets and Easter eggs, there's always something new and exciting to discover. The depth and variety of these activities ensure that even after completing the main story, the game continues to offer endless hours of entertainment.

In summary, Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas is a true gaming masterpiece that set new standards for open-world games. Its vast and immersive world, compelling storyline, memorable characters, and unparalleled freedom make it an absolute must-play for any gamer. Whether you're a long-time fan of the series or new to the Grand Theft Auto franchise, San Andreas is an experience that will leave a lasting impression and remind you why video games are an art form. Get ready to embark on an unforgettable journey through the criminal underworld of San Andreas.

I will be totaly honest here, ik that a lot of people will get angry for giving san andreas a ''not reccomended'' review, but i did this simply because i consider the game not to be worth it to play in 2023 and ima tell why:
1. The story is extremly long and sometimes repetitive, i like games with good stories but everything has a limit. GTA V took only 2 days to complete the storyline, gta 4 took longer indeed but considering the game's physycs and mission design completing gta 4 was satisfying also because of how well the intrigue was made but san andreas's story is simply repetitive, u play as Carl Johnson ''CJ'' and u get to do some missions so in the end u get ur brother out of jail but these missions, most of them, are hard to complete due to being no checkpoints so if u fail a mission u must go back and restart the whole mission not to say that u gotta travel to the place where the mission is triggered wich is really a pain. This game literally takes months to complete and the physycs of it will really not make it enjoyable.
2. The controls of the original game are HORRIBLE, besides this the missions design is a very good one for its time even ahead of it but the problem is that  some missions are literally made in such a way that they represent a torture to complete, like i remmember that mission where i had to fly with a plane and stay low so the radar wont see me so i would die a  lot simply because flying controls are horrible and because i would get hit by trees that would not render cuz yes 2004-2005 game what ya expect? or zeros missions but at least these were optional. 
3. GTA san andreas OG version is not avaible anymore on the steam store and the only way to legit buy it is to buy  a key from eneba wich is extremly overpriced in my opinion considering that i payed only 3 euros in early summer 2021 for this game. The definitive edition is basically same game, same physycs, only with more bugs and better graphics and also checkpoints so u dont have to restart the whole mission (this is the only thing i like about san andreas remaster) but is overpriced too considering the normal price is 60 euros and on sale rn it only reaches like 30 euros. 
4.Some people play this game because of how easy to mod it is and for how many mods there are but i think gta 5 got an even better modding part than gta san andreas so just go buy gta 5 if u dont have it already and mod it, belive me it will be way more enjoyable.
In the end, gta san andreas was a game really ahead of its time but tbh i would not reccomend to try in 2023 simply due to how expensive the game kinda is right now for what it has to offer. I belive that the reason why this game is still popular is because gta fans  got bored of waiting for gta 6 since we didnt have a new gta 6 game since 2013 wich is true but i want to say that in fact rdr2 is ,in my opinion, gta 6 but in the wild west so really reccomend that game to try. Anyways, gta 6 approaches and it might come very soon and i can guarantee that if it will be a ground breaking game everybody will play gta 6 and most people will forget about gta san andreas and literally all gta games besides gta 6 ofc in general (thats what happened when gta 5 came out, gta 3 and gta vc back then were really really popular but when gta 5 came they died and i really thing gta san andreas is next).
If lets say this game would be remade and it would have modern physycs and graphics and the missions wont be a pain in the ass and made enjoyable then this game would probably be the best game but until that happens is just obsolete.

There is not a lot to say about San Andreas that has already been said. It is an amazing open world game and one of the best games in the GTA series (my personal favourite being GTA IV). It brought a lot of new features to the already established open world genre, such as the ability to move the camera with the mouse or right thumbstick. This game is a must play for fans of open-world games and the GTA Series. 

The Steam version is okay, but it doesn't have the control standards of other PC games so when you turn on the game for the first time, you should definitely go into control settings and change the controls. Additionally, Rockstar updated the game after the Hot Coffee scandal, specifically causing the game to crash on the loading screen whenever a mod is installed. In order to fix this, you have to downgrade the game back to version 1.0. I would still play this version over the console editions because of the wider range of control options.

This is definitely one of the best, if not the best, games of the Grand Theft Auto franchise, however, the Steam version isn't really all that good. In my opinion, downgrade it, just look for GTA San Andreas Steam downgrader. (That's why I only have 42 hours, I actually played it a LOT more, steam just doesn't recognize it because the game folder is outside of steamapps.) If you need a tutorial, probably best that you don't do it or you're going to break your game. Backup everything, and start messing with it, modloader, cleo, go on the internet and look for whatever you wish, you can find a bunch of cool stuff really easily, it's really intuitive to mod it, and makes the experience so much better. Just SkyGfx for that PS2 filter and some bugfixes and you're good to go if you like the vanilla experience. If you don't mind the horrible Steam version, go ahead, download it and play it as is, you'll be missing out, but the game is awesome nevertheless. If you have experience with modding and/or have a triple digit IQ, you can probably make the game a lot better, without messing with the immersion and original feel of the game. I don't know if Rockstar or Steam cares, but it's a singleplayer 20 year old game, who cares if I mess with the files? My game. I bought it. I supported both Steam and Rockstar by buying it. Anyway, if you're looking for an honest review of the game, it's good, not perfect, as are all old games, but really awesome. The story is definitely enjoyable, the missions are fun and intuitive, the atmosphere and feel of the game is very enjoyable, 90's California, what a dream... Even though it's a game older than me, I still play it to this day.
What can I say this game is a classic 8.5/10 not the best GTA but still great.

Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas remains an iconic and influential game that set new standards for open-world gaming upon its release. From the moment you step foot in the sprawling state of San Andreas, you are immersed in a living, breathing world that is teeming with life and opportunity.

One of the standout features of San Andreas is its immense scope and attention to detail. The game's map is expansive and varied, featuring bustling cities, suburban neighborhoods, lush countryside, and even deserts. Each area is intricately designed, capturing the essence of 1990s California and offering a sense of realism and authenticity. The vibrant and diverse environments create a dynamic backdrop for the game's missions and activities, making exploration a rewarding and captivating experience.

Ah yes, GTA San Andreas... it has been a while my old friend....

GTA:SA, the game that's streets I knew better than my own neighbourhood and still can find my way around today easier than I can reverse out my own driveway. 
Back when I was a mere console peasant, there were soooo many extra hours in a day back then. 
Bachelor hood was the life, work all day, come home to a cold beer, a fresh bag of cheesy puffs and some sweet mary-jane and then the sweet sound of a PS booting up and that intro music kicking in.
It took me 7 years to 100% SA back in the console days, now days I get too sidetracked destroying things!

GTA:SA is a great game. Sure there are newer GTA's out there, but SA was always destined to be different. To me, it's home. Grove street was where it was at, taking selfies with your homies, robbing houses in the night and cruising the streets starting gang wars in the day, listening the the best soundtrack ever made while flying through air to get that stunt bonus, riding a bmx up and down the mountains and realising your flying skills needed work, dodging tanks and derailing freight trains.... 

Nothing takes me back to better days that playing this game.

100% the greatest game I have ever played in my life. Not because of its gameplay, its graphics, its story line or anything like that, because of the memories I have of the great times I had while playing it. But its also a great game and for it's time, it was and always will be the best game of its era.
The best game in the PS2 era of GTA, absolutely worth buying. Oh wait, you can't buy it anymore and can only buy the shitty $60 remaster instead. Fuck you Rockstar.

A Revolutionary Open-World Adventure - Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas

Rating: ★★★★★

Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas remains a timeless masterpiece that set the standard for open-world gaming. Released over a decade ago, this iconic title continues to captivate players with its vast, immersive world, engaging storyline, and unmatched level of freedom.

Set in the fictional state of San Andreas during the early 1990s, the game follows the journey of Carl "CJ" Johnson, a former gang member returning to his hometown after the death of his mother. The narrative delves into themes of family, loyalty, and the gritty realities of gang life, delivering a compelling and memorable storyline that keeps players invested throughout.

The sprawling open world of San Andreas is a marvel in itself. From the bustling streets of Los Santos to the rural countryside and the gang-infested territories, the sheer size and diversity of the map are staggering. The attention to detail is astounding, with dynamic weather, realistic NPC behavior, and a vast array of activities and missions to undertake.

One of the game's standout features is its unparalleled freedom. Players can explore the vast landscape, engage in side activities such as gambling, racing, and even customizing CJ's appearance. The ability to interact with a wide range of characters, each with their unique personalities and stories, adds depth to the world and makes it feel alive.

The gameplay mechanics strike a balance between accessibility and complexity. Driving mechanics are intuitive, gunplay feels satisfying, and the RPG-like progression system allows players to enhance CJ's skills and attributes over time. The missions are varied and offer a mix of thrilling action, clever storytelling, and creative objectives, ensuring there's never a dull moment.

The soundtrack of Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas deserves special mention. With an extensive collection of licensed tracks from the '90s, spanning various genres, the radio stations in-game provide an immersive and nostalgic backdrop to the gameplay experience.

While the visuals may show their age by today's standards, the art direction and attention to detail in the environment remain impressive. Additionally, the PC version offers a modding community that has breathed new life into the game, allowing players to enhance graphics, add new content, and extend the replay value.

Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas is a true gaming classic that has left an indelible mark on the industry. Its rich open world, compelling storyline, and unparalleled level of freedom continue to captivate players of all generations. Whether you're revisiting it for the nostalgia or experiencing it for the first time, this game is an absolute must-play for any fan of open-world adventures.

Vice City is still my favourite, perhaps due to nostalgia and perhaps due to the 1980s vibe being done so well, but this game is undeniably better. It really is Rockstar (North)'s masterpiece. A long story, varied game play, flying planes (while still frustrating at first) is done well enough that it can be a part of a whole bunch of story missions, memorable characters. An absolutely glorious soundtrack. While this doesn't look great, given its age, mods can make it look presentable on a modern system. Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas is an all-time classic that has left a lasting impression on the gaming community, particularly those of us who grew up in the early 2000s. The game's sprawling open world, compelling story, and memorable characters have made it a beloved classic that still holds up to this day.

One of the standout features of San Andreas is its nostalgic appeal. For many of us who played this game as kids, it brings back fond memories of late nights spent exploring its vast open world, causing chaos and mayhem, and engaging in epic car chases and shootouts. The game's vibrant and colorful setting, with its 90s-inspired soundtrack and iconic locales such as Los Santos, San Fierro, and Las Venturas, all add to the nostalgia factor.

But beyond its nostalgic appeal, San Andreas is also an incredibly well-designed game. The story is engaging and well-written, with memorable characters such as CJ, Big Smoke, and Officer Tenpenny, all brought to life by fantastic voice acting performances. The game's open world is vast and filled with endless possibilities, from robbing banks and hijacking planes to racing cars and engaging in street fights.

The graphics and sound design in San Andreas are also impressive, especially considering the game's age. The game's visuals are colorful and detailed, with decent character animations and pretty environments. The game's soundtrack is also top-notch, with a wide variety of music from various genres and eras, perfectly capturing the vibe of the 90s.

This game was a gargantuan milestone upon release. The leap between Vice City and San Andreas was absurd. 

Even after almost twenty years, the game still holds up fantastically, IMO. Despite the obviously outdated visuals, the gameplay is still top notch. The narrative and voice work is also excellent. The world of San Andreas is one of the most engaging in any open world game. If you enjoy open world games, then San Andreas is an excellent buy.

I am so glad I have this version of the game.  GTA:SA has been one of my favorite nostalgic games for nearly twenty years. CJ's story is the best of the GTA series in my opinion. Tenpenny is a fantastic villain. The music is out-of-the-park good.  And hell, sometimes I just love listening to the WCR talk radio as I do some low-stakes side missions.

I like this one better than the more recent GTA games, which just seemed to have more time-sinks in them. I recently got a GPD Win Max portable gaming laptop and rediscovered the joy of playing this game while out-and-about.  This game is just....fun.

10/10.  Still holds up nearly two decades later.

in 2023 overrated imo, the game does not hold up as everyone will claim. the steam version of this game has so many bugs like your sensitivity vertically is always higher than the horizontal and armour upgrades not working. its not just bugs that make this game bad, I usually try to sit through every game and give it as much chances as possible even completing every game so I can say they're bad after experiencing everything there is to but this shit was SO boring I literally couldn't get myself to finish it, it's literally a chore. The entire playthrough is just me waiting till it gets better but guess what, the community of this game agrees itself that the further you are in the game the worse it gets so better never came. the story was dogsheite imo so many stupid choices made for the sake of the story, not being able to restart missions doesn't add to the happiness of completing them like a lot of people say, it's just fucking annoying holding my breath near the end of every mission because i don't want to replay it again. I wouldn't mind replaying them if the missions were actually fun but it's not exactly fun driving from point a to point b to kill someone to drive to point c and finish the mission over and over and yeah there are exceptions (most of those exceptions still being bad lmao) but most missions are mainly what i said before with the point a poit b. this imo is the most over rated gta game in the whole franchise I seriously cannot see why anyone would recommend or even say that it's the best one out of them all. people praise the game often for the rpg elements but they're so mid? I myself like grinding and levelling up and stuff in games but in san andreas its just painfully boring, im sorry but going to the gym to spam 2 buttons repeatedly for a minute isn't exactly fun, even gta 5 does this better and that games rpg elements arent that great. if you have nostalgia for this game I can see why you're able to ignore the flaws and still enjoy it but I don't and I've come into this game after being spoiled with the modern games so I'm gonna be bias but I regret buying this. but I can't deny this game is what sparked a ton of great projects and took a huge part to getting gaming where it is today.

The protagonist, CJ, has a well-developed character arc, and the story tackles relevant themes such as racism and gang violence in a thought-provoking way. The game's open-world design allows for player agency, creating a sense of freedom and immersion. Overall, GTA SA's story is one of the best in the series and a classic in gaming.

MTA and SA-MP are must-haves for GTA SA players because they offer unique multiplayer experiences with a variety of custom game modes and features that extend the game's lifespan and add new layers of enjoyment. They also provide a thriving community that continues to support and develop mods, maps, and servers for the game.

Let me tell you, Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas is an absolute masterpiece. This game has stood the test of time and remains one of the greatest games ever made. With its vast open-world, excellent storyline, and immersive gameplay, San Andreas offers players an unforgettable experience that they won't soon forget.

The game offers over 200 hours of content, which is absolutely incredible. And let's not forget about all the hidden secrets and Easter eggs scattered throughout the game.

But what really sets San Andreas apart from other games is its attention to detail. From the way the cars handle, to the different weapons available, everything feels so realistic. And the fact that you can customize your character's appearance and even build up your own gang just adds to the already impressive depth of the game.

Now, if you haven't played San Andreas before, I urge you to go out and buy it right now. 

So, what are you waiting for? Get out there and experience one of the greatest games of all time!

Grand Theft Auto San Andreas is an incredible game that offers an immersive and thrilling experience that still holds up today. From the moment you start playing, you're transported into the sprawling state of San Andreas, with its diverse environments, memorable characters, and engaging gameplay.

The game's mechanics are well-crafted, with a perfect balance of driving, shooting, and exploration that keep the game engaging and challenging. The game's vast open-world is filled with hidden treasures, side quests, and unique challenges that will keep you coming back for more. The game's story is also a strong point, with a complex and well-written narrative that explores themes of loyalty, betrayal, and redemption.

But what truly sets San Andreas apart from other games in the franchise is its attention to detail and memorable characters. From the charismatic CJ to the ruthless Big Smoke and the corrupt Officer Tenpenny, the game is filled with memorable personalities that make the world feel alive and dynamic.

And of course, who can forget the infamous train mission where Big Smoke yells "All you had to do was follow the damn train CJ!" It's just one of many memorable moments that have made San Andreas a beloved classic in gaming history.

Overall, Grand Theft Auto San Andreas is a game that should be experienced by all fans of open-world games, action games, or simply anyone looking for an immersive and engaging gaming experience. With its incredible gameplay, intricate story, and unforgettable characters, San Andreas is a game that will stay with you long after you've put down the controller. All you have to do is play the game and experience it for yourself.

Jezus Christ San Andreas.

What I want to know is how tf this game exists. It came out on the SAME console as GTA III and Vice City. SA puts both of those games to shame. By some divine miracle the game map is like 4-6 times larger, more detailed, there's more cars, there's light RPG elements, clothes and customization of your character AND cars, There's swimming now, There's vehicles for land, sea, and air! Jets! JETPACKS! Fucking heists! There's a Las Vegas! An insane soundtrack, amazing weather systems, mini games, dancing, racing... Fucking hell this is maximum R* whatever they were smoking when they made III and VC, well they stopped and got serious. Really serious. Aside from the visuals, this game easily stands the test of time, and beats out games that drop to this day. Compare this world to Cyberpunk for Christ's sake. R* truly stumbled upon some divine essence of pure creation in 2004 and well, if they sold their souls to make the best open world games ever, it was well worth it.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game as a present from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

The world of GTA SA is better than that of GTA 4. You have 3 cities, numerous villages and counties, countryside, ghost towns, hills, rivers, lakes, dams, bridges and what not! In GTA 4, you have only one city and nothing else. In GTA SA, you can fly planes, drive trains, swim underwater and parachute. All these features are absent in GTA 4 (parachuting is available in the Ballad of Gay Tony). GTA SA driving experience is also way much better. Of course, being a newer game, GTA 4 graphics and features are way much better but I would have loved it even more if they had retained the above mentioned features of GTA SA and added at least a few villages, towns and a small countryside.

Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas is a classic game that truly stands the test of time. The game immerses players in a sprawling open world that is bursting with life and personality. From the colorful characters to the vibrant scenery, every detail is expertly crafted to create a truly immersive experience. The gameplay is endlessly entertaining, with a mix of driving, shooting, and exploration that keeps players engaged for hours on end. Overall, Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas is a timeless masterpiece that continues to captivate and inspire players to this day.

Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas, also known as GTA: San Andreas, is an absolute masterpiece of a video game. This game is a classic in the world of open-world action-adventure games, and it continues the Grand Theft Auto series' tradition of providing players with an immersive and entertaining gaming experience.

One of the standout features of GTA: San Andreas is its huge and detailed open-world. The game's world of San Andreas is vast and diverse, and players can explore every corner of it, from the bustling cities to the quiet countryside. The game's graphics are also top-notch, with detailed character models and environments that bring the world to life.

Another great aspect of GTA: San Andreas is its engaging and well-written story. The game's protagonist, CJ, is a complex and likable character, and the game's narrative is filled with twists and turns that keep players on the edge of their seats. And the game's voice acting is top-notch, with talented actors bringing the characters and world to life.

In addition to its great story, GTA: San Andreas also features fantastic gameplay. The game's missions are a blast to play, and they range from fast-paced car chases to explosive shootouts. And with its wide variety of weapons and vehicles, players can tailor their playstyle to suit their preferences and take on the city in their own unique way.

Another standout feature of GTA: San Andreas is its diverse and entertaining side missions. Players can participate in a wide range of activities, including street racing, taxi driving, and vigilante missions, that provide hours of additional entertainment. And with its huge and detailed open-world, players are sure to find plenty of secrets and hidden treasures to uncover.

In conclusion, Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas is an absolute classic in the world of video games. With its huge and detailed open-world, engaging story, fantastic gameplay, and entertaining side missions, GTA: San Andreas is a must-play for fans of the series and newcomers alike. So if you're looking for an unforgettable gaming experience, be sure to check out Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas!

I always thought this game was the pinnacle of gaming, having never played it. The best selling game on the PS2 (the best selling console of all time)? My GTA experience was the HD generation of 4 and 5, so going backwards to play this felt very clunky in controls. The map design, for as well representative of the cities as they were at the time, doesn't even come close to the level of immersion in later Rockstar games. Even the story, featuring as many memorable characters, voices, and memes as it does (who can recite Big Smoke's order?), didn't keep me interested in what happens to the Grove Street gang when Rockstar has told better stories than this in the Red Dead series. 

Calling this a classic is deserved considering how monumental it's impact on the gaming industry it was when it released (see every open-world game after 2005), and how much it influenced public perception of later GTA games (the hate on 4's serious story and seeming lack of fun vs. 5's return to Los Santos and blockbuster action). For someone like me who played through my favorite Rockstar game in Red Dead Redemption, San Andreas isn't as well put together as I had hoped.

GTA San Andreas is the magnum opus of the GTA 3D trilogy. This game was so ambitious and I sure had a blast playing this from beginning to end. I told myself I would at least try to beat the trilogy without cheats and glitches and I gotta say sometimes I can't believe this game fit on a DVD disc with how much content this game throws at you. Memorable Characters from Woozie, Big Smoke, The Truth etc. I admire where it takes CJ story wise in his miscellaneous adventures through the state that is San Andreas. I played this with the Definitive Project Mod installed (HD Textures, 60 FPS etc.) and I did not have any issues or errors for the game. It was smooth as butter which says alot due to how much stuff can be thrown into the game itself! If you are wondering if you should give this game a try again. I would say absolutely of you managed to pick this up before Rockstar pulled the games! This game will make you go "Ahh shit here we go again"
