where does one even start a review about this game?

at the time of writing this review, i have over fifty hours of gameplay in this game, and i have just completed all the story missions. yet, according to the game, i'm only a little bit over halfway done with everything there is to do in this game. how the hell did they put so much content in a 2004 game?

GTA:SA is so many things at once
firstly, it's a driving simulator of 212 individual vehicles: various cars, bicycles, motorcycles, boats, aeroplanes, trucks with or without trailers, harvesters, tractors, tanks, helicopters, so on and so forth... each vehicle has its own personality and feel, and feels different to drive. 

it's an excellent single-player FPS, which often feels very similar to games like Goldeneye 007. the firearms feel great and shoot out missions can be very challenging, requiring great strategy, practice and planning

it's an endless adventure game. the giant map has so much to see and discover that, even with dozens of hours in the game, you continuously find new stuff you've never seen before

it's an open-world game. you can do whatever the hell you want and you genuinely feel like you're even more than the main character.

it has phenomenal writing and some of the greatest cutscenes i've had the chance to watch in gaming. the game is written much like an extravagant hollywood action film, and with how self-aware it is, it succeeds at doing that much better than a vast majority of hollywood films. each character has an immense depth, sensibilities and the player gets attached. let me just say that the ending left me completely jawdropped.

it is such a perfect satire of everything that is wrong with american society, and while its absurdism gives it a certain step back from reality, now that i've visited some of the worst ghettos in the american south, and the more knowledgeable i get about american culture and politics, i feel like GTA:SA got a whole lot right about sociocultural issues in america.

it's truly a masterpiece. it's challenging, it makes you think, and it is phenomenally written. a must play. will definitely get through the rest of this game to 100% it.

If you somehow didnt play GTA SA you for sure should reconsider your desision. I highly recommend this game to everybody. Big big thumb up.

If this is the only way you can get your hands on this great game, do it. I don't care how shit the port is, I've not had too many issues with it other than occasional annoying crashes. Honestly, the game is fantastic. A huge improvement on basically everything from VC. Great story, the best music selection in any GTA, the best characters in any GTA, really tight driving controls, quite possibly the dumbest AI in any GTA, brilliant and fun storymode missions, the atmosphere of San Andreas, its forests, its deserts, its three cities, is phenomenal. Freeroam is still fun as ever, just driving around, getting your wanted level up, trying to see how long you can last, classic GTA goodness. Only real complaints about the game are the offputting graphical bugs and a few annoying side missions, but other than that, it's a masterpiece.

[h1]Introduction:[/h1]
Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas, developed by Rockstar North and released in 2004, is an open-world action-adventure game set in the fictional state of San Andreas. I was excited to play this game because of its reputation as one of the most iconic and influential titles in the GTA series.

[h1]Gameplay:[/h1]
The gameplay in GTA: San Andreas is primarily focused on completing missions and activities as you progress through the story. These missions range from simple fetch quests to more complex heists and action sequences. The controls are fairly intuitive and responsive, although there is a bit of a learning curve when it comes to the driving mechanics. One unique feature of the game is the ability to customize your character's appearance and skills by exercising, eating, and participating in mini-games. I didn't encounter any major bugs or glitches during my playtime.

[h1]Story:[/h1]
The story follows protagonist Carl "CJ" Johnson as he returns to his hometown of Los Santos after the death of his mother. He becomes embroiled in a gang war and must navigate the dangerous and corrupt world of San Andreas while trying to clear his name and protect his family. The characters are well-developed and the story is engaging, with a good mix of drama, humor, and action. The pacing is mostly well-done, although there are a few slow points where the story drags.

[h1]Graphics and Sound:[/h1]
The visual style of GTA: San Andreas is gritty and realistic, with detailed character models and environments. The graphics hold up well for a game that is over a decade old, although there are some rough edges and texture pop-in. The sound design is excellent, with a great soundtrack featuring a mix of licensed music and original compositions, as well as high-quality voice acting and sound effects.

[h1]Replay Value:[/h1]
GTA: San Andreas has plenty of replay value, with a long campaign that can take upwards of 40 hours to complete, as well as numerous side missions and activities to keep you busy. There are also multiple endings depending on your choices throughout the game, which adds some replay value. In addition, the game has a robust multiplayer mode that allows you to join or create your own game sessions with friends or strangers.

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]
Overall, I enjoyed my time with GTA: San Andreas and would recommend it to fans of open-world games and the GTA series. The gameplay is solid, the story is engaging, the graphics and sound are good for the time, and there is plenty of content to keep you busy. The controls can be a bit finicky at times and the pacing can drag in places, but these are minor issues in the grand scheme of things. If you're looking for a classic open-world game with plenty of action and freedom, GTA: San Andreas is definitely worth checking out.

Where do I even begin with GTA San Andreas? This game has been a staple in my gaming diet for almost two decades now and it still holds up remarkably well. From the moment I boot it up and hear that iconic intro song, I'm immediately transported back to a time where life was simpler and all I had to worry about was causing chaos in the streets of Los Santos.

Speaking of causing chaos, the replayability of this game is off the charts. Whether I'm trying to 100% the game or just messing around with friends online, there's always something new to do. And let's not forget about the endless supply of mods available for this game. From graphical overhauls to completely new storylines, the modding community for GTA SA is still alive and well.

But for me, the biggest draw of this game is the nostalgia factor. I can't even count how many hours I spent playing this game as a teenager and it brings back so many fond memories. And let's not forget about the amazing soundtrack, which has become a hallmark of the GTA series. Who doesn't love cruising down the highway with some old school hip hop blaring from the radio?

And let's not forget about SA-MP, the fan-made multiplayer mod for GTA San Andreas. This thing has breathed new life into the game and it's a blast to play with friends. It's a testament to the staying power of this game that it still has such a dedicated and active community all these years later.

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

why not

[u]What I liked about the game[/u] 
[list]
[*]	Likable characters, like Carl, Big smoke, Rider and Caesar who are well voice-acted. Samuel L Jackson also does a fantastic job of voice acting officer Tenpenny.
[*]	Brilliant and well done cut-scenes which have a comedy element to them. 
[*]	Fantastic story, you re-build your reputation in San Andreas. The game is very well paced. Sub-missions, new areas and weapons unlock as you progress through the game.  
[*]	This game seems to have an endless about of missions. You have the main missions plus you have a shit load of sub-missions like ambulance, cops, taxi, Freight, arena, the list goes on. The sub-missions are very rewarding as well, for example, once you complete the ambulance missions your health increases to 150% and the cop missions increases your armour to 150%. When you complete the arena unique vehicles spawn in the arena car park. 
[*]	Plenty of things to spend your money on; like clothes, jewellery, businesses, cribs and cars. 
[*]	Large selection of vehicles to drive, from cars, planes, boats, and motorbikes. Each vehicle type also has its own driving school which when you complete unlocks unique vehicles. 
[*]	An amazing soundtrack. My favourite radio station was probably radio Los Santos.
[*]	San Andreas has loads of cheats. I remember me and my friend used to try out each cheat; good times.      


[u]What I disliked or was disappointed with[/u]

[*]	It's a same they couldn't have added more weapons to the game.
[*]	You will be better off using a controller for this game, because flying isn't easy with keyboard and mouse and you also can't use auto aim.
[*]	The original version of San Andreas has been replaced with a HD version from a mobile port and as a result 16 songs have been lost. The music hasn't been restored to the game. (link below to songs which have been lost).
[/list]

[u]Conclusion[/u] 

One of my all time favourite games and in my opinion is the best game in the series. San Andreas is up there with half-life 2.  If you like vice city, GTA 3 or any 3rd person open-world shooters, then I highly recommend you buy this game. Final In game progress 86.10%. 

[h1]10/10[/h1]

Penis envy (German: Penisneid) is a stage theorized by Sigmund Freud regarding female psychosexual development,[1] in which young girls experience anxiety upon realization that they do not have a penis. Freud considered this realization a defining moment in a series of transitions toward a mature female sexuality. In Freudian theory, the penis envy stage begins the transition from an attachment to the mother to competition with the mother for the attention, recognition and affection of the father.[2] The parallel reaction of a boy's realization that women do not have a penis is castration anxiety.

Genshin Impact[b] is an action role-playing game developed and published by miHoYo. It was released for Microsoft Windows, PlayStation 4, iOS, and Android in 2020, on PlayStation 5 in 2021, and is set for release on Nintendo Switch. The game features an anime-style open-world environment and an action-based battle system using elemental magic and character-switching. The game is free-to-play and is monetized through gacha game mechanics through which players can obtain new characters and weapons. The base game is expanded regularly through patches using the games as a service model.

Genshin Impact takes place in the fantasy world of Teyvat, home to seven nations, each of which is tied to a different element and ruled by a different god. The story follows the Traveler, who has traveled across countless worlds with their twin sibling before becoming separated in Teyvat. The Traveler travels in search of the lost sibling with their companion Paimon and becomes involved in the affairs of Teyvat's nations.

Development of Genshin Impact began in 2017. The game generally received positive reviews, with critics praising its combat mechanics and the immersive open world but criticizing its simplistic endgame and monetization model. It had a first-year launch revenue of more than $3 billion in its first year of release, the highest for any video game, and a revenue of more than $4 billion as of March 2022.

This game is my childhood, and hands down the greatest game of its time. The characters and settings are written really well so that one second you laugh at how parodied some of them are, and next second you're shocked by how accurate even the parodies turn out to be. The story is amazing, and it had mechanics that seemed way ahead of its time for a triple-A game, like the ability to work out affecting how buff/skinny you are, getting more proficient at using guns just by using them, etc etc. It's a must have, and I would recommend buying it to anyone, but there is ONE problem...
Take-Two's greed knows no bounds and they removed it from the Steam page.. why? To sell their broken mobile port Defective Edition, on their own shitty and dysfunctional launcher.

If I'm gonna pick 1 game from my childhood years its going to be GTA San Andreas. I keep coming back to this game every now and then despite finishing the game loads of times in Playstation 2 and now I'm playing it on PC. The game is timeless, the story is good, this game was something out of the ordinary at the time of its release. It never gets boring playing and driving through the streets and freeways of San Andreas. The music playing on the radios are mini time capsules that would remind you of simpler times when you didn't have to think about bills and going to work. If you are a kid or someone that has not played this game yet, you are in for a treat and I swear you guys are gonna love it like how we did since the early 00s. All in all GTA SA is the most dynamic GTA out of the 3D Universe games you will never run out of things to do here.

[h1]settings for testing purposes[/h1]
1) nvidia inspector FPS cap 60/61 (depending on screen tearing)
2) SilentPatchSA from https://gtaforums.com/topic/669045-silentpatch/
3) Silent ASI loader from https://www.gtagarage.com/mods/show.php?id=21709
4) 
in-game video settings->advanced: 
widescreen: ON/OFF (depending on screen tearing/off aim)
Frame limiter OFF

in-game mouse settings:
in-game: steering with mouse OFF
in-game: flying with mouse OFF

Tips: Attention, car UP/DOWN suspension controls are inverted. It is easier to switch them to pass the car suspension mission.

Sadly, you can no longer purchase this version of the game, or GTA III, or Vice City. They were taken off of Steam in favor of Rockstar's flawed "definitive editions" of each game, which are based off the mobile ports and only available through Rockstar's own games launcher. End of an era, I guess. There are other ways to find the original releases if you're knowledgeable, but this is undeniably a blow to game preservation on Rockstar's part.

Rockstar had also changed the Steam version of San Andreas from its original release. It has native Xbox controller support and higher-fidelity graphics on par with the 2014 re-release, but also less resolution options, less music tracks due to licensing issues (check [url=http://www.neogaf.com/forum/showthread.php?t=928747]here[/url] for a list of what was removed) and a couple other issues. You can find information on unofficial fixes for this stuff such as the highly recommended SilentPatch [url=https://steamcommunity.com/app/12120/discussions/0/34096318964479523/]here[/url].


Anyway. San Andreas is the fifth game in the Grand Theft Auto series, released in 2004. You've probably heard of the series if you're browsing this website, but if you haven't it's basically they're open-world sandbox games that let you simulate low-rent gangster movies. This particular entry has somewhat clunky controls compared to more modern GTA games, and its graphics weren't great even when it came out, if still charming in their own way.

But I ultimately think San Andreas is the best game in the series, even one of the best games of the 2000s, and not just because it has 'the most to do'. Grand Theft Auto V is technically higher on the 'fun scale' with superior gameplay, superior graphics and more optional side activities; it's certainly fun to play. The titles [i]before[/i] SA are really more valuable as pieces of gaming history, since they were generally more janky & limited, and even more cliched, than SA. And while SA is a functional game that absolutely has its charm - I'm partial to its pastiche of the 90s myself - that's not the main reason I'm saying it's the best.


No, my reasoning has to do with the story and the tone. GTA V's story is interesting enough in a doofy crime capers way, but the tone of that game is ultimately aggressively nihilistic and uncaring about almost anything within itself. Not to say these elements aren't present in San Andreas, but they're not nearly as strong or disheartening here.

GTA IV is better than V in this regard, I'd say, but it's not off the hook. It tried to be more serious, and while it made strides in that direction, the weight of its open-world gameplay ambitions ultimately hamstrung its story. I didn't mind its more muted tone, 'realistic' driving and lack of cheat codes (for the base game anyway), but there's no getting around the fact that having a main character who bemoans the atrocities of the Balkan Wars he survived but is perfectly able to wantonly run over pedestrians is...odd. The final act of the story resembling a cheap mafia film didn't exactly help either.

San Andreas, by contrast, doesn't just exist primarily to "poke fun" at American society so much as it tries to tell a story about a West Coast gangbanger with a heart of gold, trying to do right for his lower-class neighborhood, family and gang within the moral construct (and repressive society) he was born and raised in. It's ultimately more genuine than V because it cares enough about its characters not to utterly derail itself every time the game displays pathos for them. It's also not self-important enough to pretend that it wouldn't be a bad thing if it [i]did[/i] do that. Perhaps most importantly, it's self-aware enough not to be stony-faced at every turn it takes. It also helps that the game's loaded with memorable quotes and characters.


The characters themselves might not be particularly more savory, and certainly there's stereotypical/exaggerated behavior going on, but at least SA doesn't furiously punch in every direction or practically flash "LAUGH AT THESE SAD LOSERS WHO ARE ALSO YOU, LOSER" on the screen every time you see them interact with each other.

Not that this game is a literary masterpiece by any means, but it's the closest the series has come to that level. And while GTA IV was also trying to operate on the same level, albeit with its own direction and its own flaws, V was just a step back in this regard. There's always been puerile satire of society and voyeuristic displays of women in the 3D GTA games, including in San Andreas, and it's always gotten disheartening if you played for long enough, but SA...isn't quite as bad in this regard, I feel. There's enough determination and hope in the story for the game not to crash and burn at least, although it's long enough that it does drag in parts.


I still resent whenever the game shoves boobs, 'sexy wimmins' and other series-standard female objectification in my face without comment, of course. Nothing is perfect. I also think it's still a bit weird that CJ comes across as a pretty decent dude, perhaps the most 'good' in the series, trying to do what he can and make the best of a pretty bad situation, and yet the game still gives you the option to go on classic GTA rampages.

Maybe there's something to be said for the tension between open-world game structure and any semblance of a plot. Whatever the case may be, San Andreas doesn't gel perfectly. GTA IV suffered from this problem too, and both games - hell, pretty much the entire series - also suffer from a number of frustrating missions. Following a damn train was never so difficult.


The game world is obviously not as realistic as V's due to the technological constraints of 2004, which means that the game isn't trying to sell itself as a perfect graphical model of Real Life™ that's fatally flawed by crazy AI behavior. The game looks enough [i]like a game[/i] that it's not [i]quite[/i] as jarring when something insane happens on the street next to you. (San Andreas' modding support is at least better than V's, and I say this because I couldn't find anywhere else in the review to stick it.)


While I don't know if I'd call this one of the best games ever made, it was one of the best of the early 2000s, and still an influential classic. Find a way to play the original release if you're interested.

Of all the GTA series I've played, this is no doubt the best GTA I've ever played and it's my main favorite one. It brings me back a lot of memories, used to played it on the original PS2. I was amazed with the story, the music and everything in this game. Well, there's nothing to say anything about the game, the thing is this game is great.

The only bad thing I noticed from this game is the update, some features/music were removed or changed due to the expired music license and has issues with modern PCs. The game sets in a slightly stretched 4:3 aspect ratio, and my mouse somehow didn't work at all from the start (although it works on main menu). Frames above 60fps pretty much breaks the physics, even though this is already a bug from the start lol. So I decided to download a downgrader, and downloaded the widescreen fix and frame limiter mod to frame cap the game to 60fps, and some other side mods I'd never use it for the rest of my gameplay. The process may seem slow, but it's worth doing it.

Is it worth spending $10 for this game? Absolutely. I highly recommend you to get this if you haven't played it before and you should downgrade it before you play it.

I'll give this a 9/10

PS: If Sam Houser could make the next GTA as fun as this one instead of making a $60 ATM, I'd be more than happy

Frankly, GTA: San Andreas is the game which got me interested in the franchise. Extremely well-written, expansive, innovative and incredibly fun. CJ is one of the strongest characters Rockstar has ever developed, along with the rest of the character list. The voice acting is incredibly well-done, the music selection is (or was) second only to GTA: Vice City in my opinion. The variety of things you can do in this game is arguably second-to-none in the entire franchise, which helps Rockstar in its portrayal of a truly open world.

The graphical stylings, while outdated by today's standards, still please the eye and many parallels can be seen between this game's environment and that of Grand Theft Auto V's more recent version of Los Santos which I can't help but think about as I play this game. GTA V's environmental design would undoubtedly have suffered in my opinion had Rockstar not made GTA: SA previously.

Overall, I'd consider it a must-play for anyone interested in sandbox games, GTA as a franchise or... hell, historically notable games. This game is widely considered one of the best of all time, which makes sense, considering it was the best-selling PlayStation 2 game ever.

EDIT: This review update comes after the release of the Definitive Edition port, the Steam Deck and its certification.

I gotta say these days that while Rockstar to date hasn't seemed to change much in its anti-consumer nonsense (hopefully with an office shake-up this will have demonstrably changed with GTA VI), this version of the game keeps on keeping on. Many of the old issues still persist (missing music, physics engine tied to framerate causing frame limiter gameplay bugs, etc). The Steam Deck compatibility is pretty excellent with the exception of cheat entry (I'd advise looking into a mod which reintroduces controller-based cheat code entry) and possibly an audio bug with the Definitive Edition user mod on Linux with the latest version of Proton. But is it satisfying, more so than the mobile port, to play the best version of GTA: SA next to the launch PS2/Xbox version? Absolutely, and it's now portable-ish with the Steam Deck, I'd recommend giving it a shot. It's a welcome dose of nostalgia and time-wastery on watch.

Don't get confused by my review being set to "Not Recommended". This game is very good and is one of my favorite games of all time (as you can tell by my playtime) but I cannot recommend this release.

The primary reason is that the Steam version of San Andreas simply sucks. It's missing music, it has many bugs, it runs like trash, etc. It's pretty much worse than the original 2005 version in a lot of ways, which means that if you want the best experience, you'll need to downgrade it and get a couple of mods to make it a very enjoyable experience. Personally, I don't mind modding my game, but I can imagine many people probably won't bother modding or even know about how bad this release is, which would make them go ahead and mod it. It's been 7 years since the last patch and they still sell this busted version on Steam without fixing it. Awful.

There's also Take Two being scumbags and shutting down various mod projects, but other reviews already talked about it at length, so i'll spare you the talk here. 

Simply put, don't buy it on Steam. I recommend you get a used copy somewhere. If you don't have a DVD drive or if you absolutely NEED it on Steam, then downgrade this bad release to the original 1.0 version and get the mods. Even then, I wouldn't recommend supporting Take Two financially, so be wary of that fact if you decide to buy it on Steam.

If you'd like to know more specifics about why the Steam version is terrible, I highly recommend this comparison video made by Vadim M: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XESrzw62rlQ

I'm not going to beat around the bush. Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas is the single best PlayStation 2 title I have ever played. It's larger than the biggest RPG, has more story than the heftiest adventure game, and has almost as many mini-games as Nintendo's Mario Party. Additionally, it has a production value that's second to none, boasts a faithfulness to '90s source material with an eerie accuracy, and provides more hours of entertainment than all the previous Grand Theft Autos combined. In short, it's a terrific unending masterpiece of a game -- and one that will never fall victim to an over-exaggeration of its lofty status. It's the defining piece of software for Sony's successful sophomore system, and it's almost impossible to imagine a PlayStation 2 library without it.

An all time classic, this game will always be greatest the peak the GTA series has ever seen. It has gang wars, plenty of weapons to use, clothing variety, you can make CJ fat/skinny/buff, the story is engaging, many sidequests, lots of opportunities where you can earn easy money from the start of the game (betting horse track or stuff like ambulance/vigilante/firefighter missions), you can buy apartments and businesses, you can collect many collectibles and earn hefty rewards, you can do almost everything. 

No GTA game will ever surpass this game in terms of everything. Storywise, there are other competent games in the series, but the overall feel of this game for me is the highest in terms of positive reviews compared to the rest of the series.

Ignore the low playtime. Had to mod this game to kingdom come until it would finally run in widescreen properly, have a usable interface and a myriad of other fixes. All said and done I easily have 80+ hours in this game across multiple playthroughs, not even considering the playthrough I did over on PS4 before they also replaced that version with the definitive edition. Unimpressive graphics and shitty remaster aside, the original holds up shockingly well on just a pure fun and narrative level. If you can get around to finding this version of the game instead of the remaster and modding it to a playable state, there's a lot to enjoy. It's a shame to see Rockstar treat the whole franchise with utter disrespect like this.

A classic for a reason, and still competing as one of the most content rich open worlds, 15+ years after release. What else really needs to be said? I sincerely doubt there even is anyone who has at least not heard about this game, considering how often it is referenced and the memes it spawns even almost two decades after release. I have replayed it multiple times, owning a disc copy, and later re-bought digitally, and will likely re-play it again a couple times in the future.

Now, it is - objectively - by no means a perfect game - even during its time, the graphics were dated, and physics were rather simplistic, and unlike other GTA games, the plot had a bit of a good guys vs. bad guys vibe, which did not really make sense considering the setting and the characters. On the other hand, the open world was not only considerably larger than previous GTA games, it was also more varied in terms of locations, and was filled with content - both missions, main and side, and a variety of minigames, collectables, challenges and easter eggs. The sound direction is great, especially in regards to soundtrack and radio track selection - I still sometimes listen to the OST / radio tracks on youtube as they are really good mixes. Also, it really shows that you can make a large game, and not have it an almost unplayable bugfest (though there still were some, and not all of them got patched) at launch - yes, I'm looking at you, Bethesda.

SA is truly the definitive GTA game of the 3D era, it expanded greatly upon the content of previous games not only in regards to the mission/story content, but pretty much everything else - I would say one of the most important introductions was the (pretty extensive, all things considered) vehicle customization, which has since been considered a requirement to have in this type of open world games, and has led to criticism of games of this type that do not have it.

Anyways, if you've never played SA, I recommend to do so ASAP. There will be a lot of jank, the graphics will make your eyes bleed at times - especially if you mostly play recent AAA titles, but you'll find a lot of enjoyment and fun in the game nevertheless.

Still a lot of fun even today, shame that Rockstar no longer sells this and GTA 1, though they are freeware, Rockstar made them so like 20 years ago, so if you wanna give GTA 1 or 2 a try, definitely do that. (don’t go downloading it off every website tho. ;) )

Set in either 1999 or 2013 in Anywhere City USA, you take control of Claude Speed, who works for different gangs around Anywhere city, across 3 districts, like the Russian Mafia, Rednecks, Yakuza, etc. The game has a "respect meter" where if the meter goes down, you can't do missions for that gang, so you gotta for example, kill their rivals to gain respect from them, then do the same to other gangs when you wanna do jobs for them, kill their rivals.

If you're coming from later GTA's like IV, SA and V, this will obviously be different, and despite the game having aged somewhat badly, like the controls and camera, as well as navigation, the game can still be a blast if you look past that.

And remember, respect is everything!

• I needed to relaunch the game 3 times to make it run cause it was stuck on a black screen and I got the same problem again
• The game was stretched as hell in 16/9 i couldn't find how to fix that (the large screen mode didn't fix it, it just did "less" stretches but it didn't remove them)
And other things that made me refund it to buy Vice City instead

Why ? Rockstar why ? The game was perfectly good on the CD version why didn't you just ported the game as it was on Steam ? Why breaking the game before putting it on Steam ?

But anyway, i Googled the problems and i needed to install mods to DOWNGRADE the game
I need to DOWNGRADE a game because the actual developers of the game literally broke the game 

I know it's because they had to remove some things like some tracks that got its licenses expired but they had NO reason to remove some features and breaking the game like that

What is the point of deleting the animations of the cars ? And the adaptive dirt on the cars ? The lens flares that makes the game cooler ? The reflections when it's raining in night ? and all the things that makes the game more interesting ?

I tried to downgrade it but it didn't work and I didn't want to mess up more with the game files

You can buy it if you really want to play it, there's a solution, there's a lot of people here in the reviews saying that the game is good etc because they fixed it, but i don't want to invest time on it cause I'm not supposed to

The game is a classic, it's fun and all that but the Steam version just clears all the fun from it.

Unless you want it to work and spent maybe 1/2 hours fixing it, then you're good, it's under $10, for Gta San Andreas, it's worth it.

Edit: My friend and I are sharing our Steam games and I saw GTA SA again, but this time, I fixed it. And it's super good now. I still don't recommend the game to buy as it is but if you're willing to do some fixes it's good. Also, the Definitive Trilogy edition is coming soon so, check it out !

I want to point out a few things and its about the bugs that can break your save game.
1. The broken cheat: Theres a cheat in the game that makes peds more "Violent". After saving you just completely made a bug. this means that peds in script mission cutscenes and in game will break the game completely
2.Broken Gym:When you wanna become buff and go to the gym when you reach the limit you will soon realize that after you come back the game tells you that you have reached your limit. However if you want to avoid this stupid bug than just do not at all reach the limit. Luckily Silent fixed this bug with his patch.
3.Mad Dogg broken save: This bug happens when you save in Mad Doggs crib. you see there was a cool feature to play basketball. and Mad Dogg's crib had not only a save but also a basketball court. When you save the basketball in all areas disappear. The way to avoid this is to not save in the crib like in the ice cream factory in vc. Luckily silent fixed this bug as well. REASON: its because a save point is near a basketball so if you save I believe the game believes that you are playing basketball. But i could be wrong. Bonus: The pool game also features a bug where when you put a save pickup near the pool opponent Via mods it will also do the same thing.
4:Broken San Fierro Docks: When you are doing the import/export side missions you will realize that when you come back to the docks to bring a car on the list you real soon realize that the game will crash. unfortunately Silent was not able to fix this in his game patch.
5.Broken Territorys: one thing that Rockstar North featured is what we call "THE ENDLESS MAP" where if you take a plane and fly out of the city you were gonna keep going and going. but a bug happens where if you fly out to far for what some reasons various gangs spawn in areas like Ballas spawning in Las Venturas for example.

Whenever I talked about Grand Theft Auto to any of my friends, they would always pull a few quotes from San Andreas. I never fully understood them until I played it myself. This game has a great story, and I was invested the entire way. There are some notes that should be made before people play the game. First, the game resolution has to be at a minimum level, because a high resolution will cause the game to crash. Next, lowrider controls have the up and down arrow keys switched, so don't get frustrated. Aircraft controls are janky, so be patient.
I recommend this game highly because it is a classic. After playing it, I feel encouraged to play GTA III and give it another chance due to Catalina's appearance in this story.

What is GTA San Andreas ?

In my sincere opinion, its simply the best GTA game, the ammount and features it has is bigger than any other GTA, while it doesn't have the best story or graphics by today's standards, its the most iconic game of the series and the one that left the biggest impact, they managed to make the gameplay deep here and even more satisfying than 3/VC, there are many more side stuff to keep you occupied when you want to take a break from the missions, the soundtrack is great and the characters are just iconic, thanks to the great work of tons of famous voice actors present here such as the muthafreaking sam jackson, its a hell of a classic, the game gets even better when you consider its modding scene, theres even a multiplayer mod if you want to go further, you will see how much better it is than what the grindfest pay-to-have-fun GTA Online has become, this is a must-have game to any PC owner, a great classic.

playing san andreas in the 2020s is wild! it's clear that it was made right at that crux of budget vs ambition, before games with scope began to regulate themselves into the gears of war/assassin's creed styles of triple a gaming. as such, there's more experimentation going on here than one might think. whilst you have your GTA essentials of stealing cars and shooting the bad guys, there's also an immersive sim hidden in here, somehow.

work as a valet for 4 hours, go to the gym, get fat from too much fast food, manage your relationships, spread gang territory, cover up grafitti, do vigilante police work, train your lung capacity, we won't let you continue with the story until you train your lung capacity. a lot of this stuff does not work at all, the driving school is an absolute nightmare, but no other game does what san andreas does in that regard

it's a relic of the ps2 era, and in my mind doesn't hold up to the best of the grand theft auto series. that being said, it's an absolute cornerstone of the history of the medium, and i think you should experience it at least a little bit.

Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas is one of the best games Rockstar has ever made, the game is still very fun to play and the gameplay still holds up in 2022, at least better than III or Vice City. There are some really memorable characters in this game and there are some features of the game like exercising to become fit or eating to gain energy or become fat as all hell which can affect how people talk to you in-game which is really awesome. The game also has the best cheats in all of the GTA games out there like being able to spawn a tank and fly with it, or chaos mode. GTA: SA Is truly a fun game. There are some technical issues when playing this on a newer and more powerful pc. The fix to this without modding the game is to go to the folder where the exe is located and go to properties and set the compatibility to Windows XP and change the settings to have the frame limiter on (26fps) and there you go, you can play GTA: SA! It's really sad that Rockstar removed this game from steam to make the Definitive edition but there isn't really anything we can really do about it. :(

Gta San Andreas, as classic as classic gets. This game is pretty much the definition of a classic video game. If you haven't played San Andreas, what are you even doing with your life? Jokes aside though, this is a great game. A really good and complex story that are still being discussed to this day, even after like 18 years. There is alot of things to this game and some things that are a bit hidden, so even if you have played this game there is almost certain that there is a atleast something that you didn't know. The map is also pretty huge for such a old game. If you haven't bought it yet, just do it.

[h1] Gangsta’s Paradise. [/h1]

Like Vice City before, San Andreas perfectly encapsulates a certain Zeitgeist, this time of early 90s California, and combines it with an even bigger open-world. San Andreas is a whole state, at least four to five times bigger than Vice City, and accordingly has a lot more stuff to do and even more diverse locations to see.

Here you follow Carl „CJ“ Johnson, who comes back to his hometown Los Santos (probably the most accurate and lively depiction of Los Angeles in a videogame until the release of GTA V), after some years of abscence to find his mother murdered and his remaining family and friends deeply involved in gang wars, drug dealing and sinister machinations of corupt police officers. The story and setting are full of gangsta-yadda-yadda and ghetto clichés, so just like with Vice City, it kinda depends on your taste if you can immerse yourself into the setting and relate to the exaggerated and satirical characters. The music and voice-actors on the other hand are beyond any doubt once again. This time we got actors like Samuel L. Jackson, James Woods, Peter Fonda and Ice-T, in combination with the music of artists like Rage against the Machine, Soundgarden, 2Pac, Cypress Hill, James Brown, Rick James, Joe Cocker, Kiss, Rod Stewart, The Who, Lynyrd Skynyrd, Ozzy Osbourne, Faith no More, Depeche Mode and Jane’s Addiction, and it doesn’t stop there. For movie- and music nerds, San Andreas is heaven and it has the best cast and soundtrack in the series to date.

As was the case with Vice City, San Andreas basically sticks to the basic principles and core mechanics of GTA 3 and just adds a sh*t-ton of content in a once again greatly expanded world. Most notable added features are a greatly increased character customization system (hair- and beardstyles, clothes, tattoos, etc.) bigger arsenal of both weapons and vehicles, and even slight RPG elements: The more your character runs, swims, excercises, drives cars or uses certain weapon types, the more efficient he becomes with those things. On the other hand, if he eats too much, he gets fat and looses stamina. Furthermore there are some limited romance options for certain characters and a „turf war“ system, where you can attack and conquer the „hoods“ of rival gangs, to generate extra money. Overall, where Vice City already had a lot to offer, but was still somewhat straightforward and manageable in terms of side content, San Andreas gets lost a little and i found much of its side content a little bit overwhelming or downright unecessary at times. I think i still haven’t seen or tried everything the game has to offer until this day. 

In contrast to the amount of content, the grafics only got a slight update when compared to Vice City. The textures are slightly sharper, there are some improved lighting and weather effects and the whole world is a bit more detailed in general, but in the end the technical improvements where minimal. Nevertheless, given the sheer size of San Andreas, it is quite impressive that they could manage to improve the grafics at all, even if it was just to a very small degree.

GTA V is an amazing game, but being the nostalgic old man that I am, Vice City and San Andreas remain my favorite GTA games. Literally the only things in those two games that are rather dated are the grafics and, to some extend, slightly clumsy controls, but measured against the overall quality of the games, those flaws basically fade away. San Andreas in particular is, in my opinion, the best open-world-game ever with some of the funniest and most creative missions you'll ever have the joy to play and that makes it easily Top-50-games-of-all-time-material. 

So, finally regarding Rockstar pulling the originals from the Steam Shop in order to sell their useless and broken cash-in Remasters: See Link below.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2761426337

I have over 400 hours in this game, so I think im eligible to have an opinion on this game. The reason I dont recommend playing San Andreas with the steam version is because the patch that steam uses is broken. You will have to either cope with terrible,broken physics or 25 fps locked because of the frame limiter bugs. You are not able to mod the game in this version, so no SA-MP or MTA and no game customization at all. Besides all, these there are some minor changes that kind of ruin the game, such as vehicles are mudded all the time and many more. I would suggest you either emulate the game, or downgrade it if youre gonna buy it from Steam or Rockstar Launcher (since rockstar uses the steam patch ver.). There are a lot of downgraders for San Andreas and many tutorials on YouTube you can follow for an optimal San Andreas experience. If you downgrade to the 1.0 version of the game youre free to do whatever you want. Basically mod it to your liking, like putting a 60fps frame limiter with fixed physics, and if youre not into that, you can keep it vanilla since this version is alot better than the sub-optimal steam one by just itself.

Wow, this game is cool... you know a game is fun when you refuse to stop playing when you should (even when the constant dying offends you because you lose your weapons and some cash, so you look for cheats instead of going to bed to stop the realism, which keeps stealing your guns, all because the A.I. keeps getting headshots during missions, lol...

more on that mission later), it looks nice at very high settings, stable too... so far, but i did die (because of a bug) once when trying to save Sweet's girl... all i did was try to jump over a wall by the bridge at MainBase (which leads to instant death at full health, really weird mission) & driving is a bit nuts in the beginning as well as the reverse camera control (on the mouse).

however, beyond that cool story, really immersive and this looks like an inspiration for WatchDogs 2, i see now why people love it. so please bring this back for the love of mankind! 

This game could totally use an expansion and minor bug fixes as well as a rework on the graphics,

i finished almost everything like 94 or 96 tags, got all my girlfriends to 100% except Catalina (in less than 150 hours), she is weird. but i miss her, lol... finished the main story too.

 hehe, also thanks for not deleting it from my library... really not into that because .....it's the worst. fo real ...addictive game even in the first 10 hours, it did not disappoint... the biggest issues were A.I. instantly gunning you down when you move into their line of sight and cars flipping over like crazy, but at the end of the game, those were no longer issues that bothered me at all. Only an issue for the first 100 hours, definitely enjoyed this game for all that it had to offer. 

I never did unlock that car-dealership though... by the garage CJ buys. but the guide says how to do it, as well as i thought there was an option to unlock more GirlFriends, i need to look that up too, the game is packed with stuff to do & it's not like older games, where things get boring, very cool... we also need a GIFT MAP, of all the gifts like flowers... and other things you can give to your girlfriends.

The most iconic game of the 3D era GTA games. I remember spending hours on this game around 10 or so years ago. It never gets old. I love this game so much. This was one of my first game in the series. However, I can't bring myself to recommend this version to anyone. Throughout my whole time playing the game, it just kept crashing every 5 minutes. Heck, I couldn't even get pass the loading screen and bam! Crashed. Not only that, there are also some issues with the widescreen implementation, some content being removed, and plenty more downgrades from the PS2/Xbox versions. 
 If you wanna play San Andreas, don't buy the steam version. 

If you still want to play this version, I'd recommend downgrading it and installing some mods to make it better. There are plenty of guides out there that you could follow to achieve this.

This is easily the best out of the Playstation 2 era of GTA games.

+ Immersion
This game wants to be explored. In Los Santos you want to go to the gym and get fit. You want to do home invasions to get money and infinite sprint. In Angel Pines you want to do the Ambulance missions, and you want to drive around on a motorcycle to improve your skills.
   In San Fierro you want to take pictures.
   In Las Venturas you want to collect horseshoes

+ Missions
In comparison to GTA III and Vice City this game build on the missions. They are more elaborate, more fun and have more things to do. The dialogue while going to a mission is great and truly make you feel like you are having a real team in San Andreas.

/Story
I feel mixed about the story. The game is a bit bipolar in the way that it tells several stories, and in many ways San Andreas is split into two games.
1. Los Santos/Grove Street. Here you are Tenpenny's bitch, you fight the Ballas, you wear green, you protect your brother and build up the hood. You're gangster and live in a poor Los Santos area hustling the neighbourhood. And then it just ends...

2. After 1/3 of the game you have reached San Andreas 2. You know do more of a Vice City style of game, you can't even go to the hood anymore or you'll be shot. You are no longer a member of Grove Street, deal with it.
   The missions become really fun, both in Angel Pines, later on in San Fierro. Then it gets ridiculous in the desert and Las Venturas in true GTA fashion. This is GTA at its finest.

Back to 1: the game don't know how to end itself and you're flung back to Los Santos to claim gang territory in the middle of a Riot (this is very tedious) and then kill the people threatening the hood. It's just that you feel so disconnected with the hood at this point that it just feels... off?

Silver lining: I save the Casino heist for last to go out with a bang. This feels like a better ending in my opinion.

+ Gameplay
Gameplay is amazingly fun, but there are so many times you need to learn something new
- learn how to breath underwater
- learn how to fly
- learn how to fly the Harrier
- learn how to sneak
- take over territories
etc. etc. etc...

This goes on until the bitter end.

Los Angeles in the 1990s is the perfect time for a Grand Theft Auto game. Street crime was at it's peak back then, with gangs, organized crime and corrupt cops being the focus of this entry. A rather serious story, but not without it's silly jokes and Rockstar's signature sense of humour. Although I do think they did go a little too far when adding mechanics to the game. It has a lot of content, sometimes it gets tiring, but at least it feels polished. It's a shame the Definitive Edition removed the charm the game had back in the PS2.

This peace of art changed my life, since i was a little kid my dream was to play Grand Theft Auto. I watched a lot of gameplay videos of people playing that masterpiece when i was 6 years old and in the summer after 1st grade i finally convinced my parents to play the game. I started, i was stuck in the Cesar Vialpando mission for the whole summer but that didn't stop me. Thank you Rockstar Games, Rockstar North and the team who worked on creating the best game ever made!

Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas is a 2004 action-adventure game developed by Rockstar North and published by Rockstar Games. It is the fifth main entry in the Grand Theft Auto series, following 2002's Grand Theft Auto: Vice City, and the seventh installment overall. It was released in October 2004 for the PlayStation 2, in June 2005 for Microsoft Windows and Xbox, and in November 2010 for Mac OS X. The game is set within an open world environment that players can explore and interact with at their leisure. The story follows former gangster Carl "CJ" Johnson, who returns home following his mother's murder and is drawn back into his former gang and a life of crime while clashing with corrupt authorities and powerful criminals. Carl's journey takes him across the fictional U.S. state of San Andreas, which is heavily based on California and Nevada and encompasses three major cities: Los Santos (inspired by Los Angeles), San Fierro (San Francisco) and Las Venturas (Las Vegas).

Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas is one of my favorite childhood games, and easily my favorite PS2 game from Rockstar Games. Being a huge fan of the franchise, I beat the original San Andreas on PS2, the insanely buggy mobile port, the PS2 port on PS3, and on a lot of times on PC. There is so many things to praise about this game like the gameplay, the map, the side content, mission design (most of the time),... and a few things to point out that haven't aged the best (mostly the disjointed story),... but I don't feel like doing it as we all know how much of a classic this game is. It's such a shame that this PC port is garbage, and if Rockstar Games/Take 2 Interactive taking down mods and suing the creators wasn't enough, they removed this classic along with 3 and Vice City from all stores to promote their atrocious remaster. If you wanna relive your memories of this game, get a cheap Steam key and mod the game, or emulate the PS2 version on PCSX2.

RIP original radio stations. Get the game elsewhere, as they have the power to cripple it here.

But it's more like a store listing review. The game alone is otherwise a true gem, it's my favorite title in one my favorite game franchizes.

So, I came into this game as a person who hates the Souls-genre. I'm not that good at combat in video games as I typically like games where you can just hack or slash your way through everything. So when Elden Ring was announced and talked about pre-release, I was like "Nah, i wont like it.". Fast-forward to when it released I was watching a few friends play it and it looked amazingly fun. So I was like... I gotta bite the bullet and try it.
Lo and behold it was the best decision ever! Elden Ring while a souls-game has a feature to it that actually made it a lot more comfortable for me to play than any other souls game: It was open world without a defined path you have to take. Sure, the grace sites tell you WHERE you should go, but you can generally ignore them. Also sure, you have to beat certain things in order to "win" the game, but you can like ignore that for a really long time and just explore. I had so much fun exploring the game and just messing around with magic that it really didnt feel like a souls game until like mid-game. That's when the bosses started to get really punishing for me. However, I only had to really call in my friend like three times? One of those times was just because it was like eleven at night and I was exhausted and just really wanted to get past the boss.
So, honestly, without going further into it and allowing you to explore on your own, YES get Elden Ring, even if you typically hate Souls games. This game is literally the souls-genre redone in a way that almost anyone can get into it. One last thing to mention before i peace out, but I have REALLY bad ADHD to the point where it's rare that a game actually keeps my attention. I was absolutely hooked from start to finish with this game.

This game took some tinkering to get it to work properly. However though it runs like it should there are certain things that are absent. Example the breaking on vehicles is seemingly always active so if you stop accelerating then the break engages and I do not recall this being a thing on the original release. This game is just off-putting on certain things.

Update: Many months later I decided to try again, I dont have that weird vehicle breaking. However I cant progress any more forward because in the first few missions where you familiarize yourself with a pistol and you have to destroy a car. As soon as a vehicle explodes my game crashes. So i've essentially locked the game to just free roam. The first time I loaded up the game i was getting 200 frames and now im only getting 20-ish. No idea why, I checked the frame rate limiter and put it both on and off but to no avail.

Ahhhh A nice throwback. This game consists of an open world mechanic and amazing story. 

Story: You play as a man named CJ whose mother has recently passed away. He comes back home to realize that his family/gang isn't in good condition with the Ballas, the enemy gang. So you help restore Grove Street back to it's former glory.

Children/parents: This game consists of curse words such as "F***" and the N - word. This game makes a lot of references to sexual content. I recommend only adults or mature teenagers play. 

Graphics: Not too good. This game is over 10 years old so don't expect RTX graphics.

Summary: This game is definitely recommended for adults and people who love to mess around. Hope this helps! ~T

Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas - my favorite GTA of all time. I started playing this game in 2010 and I played it very often in all this time, especially during 2013 - 2019, when I've got into SA-MP. In terms of statistics, it's worth to say that I finished the story of this game about 30-40 times and I should have over 15,000 hours played by now if I had had this game on Steam from beginning. Even if I spent about 2 years of my life into this game, I don't regret all that time as I befriended a lot of persons and I remained with a lot of good memories.

In terms of gameplay, even after all these years, the game is still fully enjoyable and always feels nostalgic. This title was the best advancement of Rockstar Games back in 2004 and introduced a lot of new systems and mechanics, some of them aren't even present in the newer GTAs such as the ability to change the body shape of the main character. The community of GTA: San Andreas has decreased over time, but it's still active, thanks to SA-MP (even if it's an unoficially modification of the game). However, this particular version of the game (the Steam version) isn't that well made as it contains a lot of bugs I've never met before in the other versions of the game I've played. Since the launch of GTA Trilogy: The Definitive Edition, this version of the game is not longer available on Steam anyway so I don't think there should be anymore reasons to criticise it due bugs.

In conclusion, this game will always be one of my favorite games of all the time so if someone hasn't played it yet, I highly recommend: Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas - the GTA with one of the best stories of all the time and the most nostalgic radio stations.

This game has such a disconnected feeling between the ingame missions and the story. 
In the missions the main character is a thug that has little regard for anyone but friends and family. He murders cops and fbi agents in the hundreds without any problems. He can shoot down helicopters and bust fbi raids like nothing. But once in story mode Carl suddenly becomes a frightened bullied child who's pushed around like a moron and is unable to touch or even speak up against a single person that is oppressing him. It's surreal borderline retarded plot. Carl apparently can't even think of harming or attempting to fight back until his oppressors literally attempts to murder him. Then it's ok to fight.

The missions and the plot also get more and more deranged as the game goes along. As if some random blackmail would make the main character commit to serial murders and escalating violence rather then just face the blackmailing/blackmailers instead. Attacking military targets with stolen military equipment. One man facing the actual army, is in Carls eyes more preferable to attempting to attack some random blackmailers. The blackmail stunt goes on far too long.

The story also goes beyond fiction and some crackpot drug dealer suddenly orders him around attacking military bases. Just thinking about the plot in GTA san andreas is giving me a headache. There's zero decisions involved nor is there any kind of choice in the story missions from you as the player.

Most of the missions themselves are also made in the most over the top and annoying way.  
They can end instantly with some obscure bulls*it like loosing a trailer connection or running out of time. Constraints added mostly to annoy or increase difficulty instead of adding fun. Going to steal a car for your showroom? Of course there will lots of travel time to the target and then there will be fifteen henchmen guarding the car who's willing to sacrifice their lives to stop you, appearing just as you are about to leave. Why not arm them with bazookas and why not throw in some choppers as well, even better if you have someone to defend too. Failed? Oh well you just have to start all over again with the travel time and everything. 

Most of the missions I tried in this game was about as fun as pulling out teeth.
I'm convinced that the zero RC and plane school missions are made by psychopaths. 
No sane person would use controls that are that bad and unfriendly to players. 

The lack of fast travel is disgusting (the airport/train is nowhere near enough) and you often loose all your inventory again and again. Where is the finesse? Where are the quick taxis from earlier games? The game is actually devolving in some areas.

Like GTA3 and Vice City this game has a well developed city and good technological aspects but the script and missions are of disturbingly low quality.

The game's protagonist, Carl Johnson, nicknamed "CJ," is a real nigger, as rude as that sounds. Back home in Los Santos for his mother's funeral, he plunges back into gang life and throughout the storyline unites his family, showing the other clans that the Johnsons are to be reckoned with.

He is hindered and aided in his goal by a myriad of characters: friends, enemies, idiots, etc. Not all of the characters are well written out, but there are no questions about the voice acting. Whether it's the corrupt cop Tenpenny or the awesome bitch Catalina, you won't feel the slightest bit fake.

The available territory is steeply spread out. In the fictional state of San Andreas fit California with copies of its two famous cities (Los Angeles and San Francisco) and a piece of Nevada, where a clone of Las Vegas has settled freely.

And at first, the plethora of things to do in this world is eye-opening. At first we learn that CJ has acquired personal data, learned how to lose weight and get fat, build muscle and even ... eat. True, the excitement fades slightly when it turns out that all the novelties, unusual for GTA - just children's toys, the appearance of real life (to the toilet, fortunately, do not go). In the spirit of The Sims. Of course, lovers of sitting in a snack bar over time will turn into a walking donuts, and adherents of bodybuilding increase endurance (it allows you to run / swim longer in the "super sprint" mode) and happy to defile the streets without outerwear, but die of hunger here can not, and drive and shoot fighters and overweight the same way.

In addition to the purely natural needs, our doppelganger has acquired Barbie doll tendencies. Players who are tired of looking at the same shirt can do grooming Carl - dress him up, cut his hair and put tattoos on almost all parts of his body (car tuning is not as detailed - a bunch of "dodgers", a modest selection). And in each city - a new assortment. It is frightening to imagine what would have happened if they had made a woman the main protagonist of SA...

The numerical characteristics of the game once again jumped, reaching the marks "40+" (types of weapons) and "200+" (cars, planes, boats, bikes and motorcycles with ATVs). The found dildo is a lot of fun to beat up townspeople, using it instead of a bat, and the harvester is not bad for bloody reaping. The physics of the car has changed slightly, as well as the damage model. But actually, not many people resented it before, either. But the ancient trick with cars disappearing behind could have been fixed.

The graphics in San Andreas are a hymn to juicing. Especially when you consider how old the Renderware engine is and how many games haven't used even half of its power. Correct shadows, which became a must-have attribute everywhere, have only now reached GTA. By the way, here they are not nailed down, but move according to the sun and other light sources.

The exploration and side content is definitely an upgrade compared to GTA 3. There's a lot more and a greater variety to do, which makes the world feel that much bigger and more vibrant (tho if you don't care for 100% stay far far away from the police and freight train missions). Story-wise there's a lot of obnoxious characters that just make you question when the game's gonna end them and thankfully it does most of them. And honestly was quite happy to be on good terms with Woozy and Truth til the end cause if I had to kill the only truly likeable characters I would've been pretty annoyed. I played without any mods so final tips if you don't feel like bothering to get any fixes is to run the game in Windows 7 compatibility, save as often as you can because the game sure does crash, when you swim make sure to turn frame limiter (aka lag) on because without it you swim very slowly and can't dive.

I love these games, especially GTA:SA and even though they're 20 years old they still work on modern hardware, with a few tweaks. That being said, I cannot justify recommending the new editions to anyone as they were very clearly rushed, and relying on Rockstar to patch a game after you have already paid for it is rolling the dice. 

It is very unfortunate that we live in a time with the best technology, and the greediest game developers. Eventually the consumer will realize they don't need to impulsively buy everything even if it is bad, but until then we are here waiting for devs to actually care about putting out a quality game, not just a remake made by interns. 

If Rockstar had done a legit remake/remaster, buying the Definitive Edition would be a "no brainer", but as it is right now, I believe you should pirate the older version of the games and then patch them over buying the new versions. Fuck you Rockstar.

With the somewhat recent release that is the awful remaster of the grand theft auto trilogy, Rockstar Games has decided to remove the ability for people who want to purchase the original formats of these games from the steam store. They named the re release of these games the definitive edition, which I find underwhelming. They missed out the opportunity to name the re remaster the Limited Edition, as in, that is the only fucking way you can get the games any more without pirating them.

Asides from that, Grand Theft Auto San Andreas is one of the best video games of all time, including so many features, vehicles, and elements that other games of this era couldn't even come close to being this inclusive. It still holds up and is very playable if you are willing to deal with a lot of issues, one of them being not having the option to give rockstar your money anymore to play their game. lmao.

The first thing players will notice is that the mouse straight up doesn't work when you load your save file. You have to open up task manager, finger your butt hole, and switch back to the game like Indiana Jones with the sandbag in raiders of the lost ark just to get the game to work. And trust me, this does not work the first try. You will open task manager 5 times before you coax your game into working properly. 
Then you will get through about 14 hours of game play and hit a group of missions that have a lot more ridiculous issues that require other juvenile fixes to overcome. 
When you reach the amphibious assault mission, you will not be able to play it because you won't have the lung capacity skill built up enough to do the mission, unless you've been swimming underwater like an asshole for some reason. Which is exactly what you have to do for about 15 minutes before you have enough skill built up for you to be able to start the mission. 
But there is one problem; the swimming doesn't work. It just doesn't work. So you go on google, type in gta san andreas cant swim and what do you know, you have to turn the frame limiter on in order for the game to work, because if you have a half way decent computer to play on, you are playing at way higher frames than the game was ever intended to play on when the game was developed a nearly a whole 2 decades ago.
So now you are playing at 26 fps which is worse than accidentally drinking orange juice for breakfast after brushing your teeth, then you finish the mission and go on to do the driving school mission.
oh boy.
Mission 1, complete 1 donut in a vehicle. It just, it won't do it. I can hold w and s and do a burnout all day long but trying to get another key on my keyboard to activate just wont happen for whatever reason. I don't know if this is an issue with my keyboard or a general issue with many types of keyboards that possibly limit how many keys can be depressed at one second, but all I know is issues like rockstar not letting fans buy their game any more makes me big time depressed

Basically, this game is awesome and requires you to do some research sometimes to overcome small issues with the game being 17 years old this is to be expected and low key kind of nostalgic because I feel like that is the sort of stuff you had to do with old games of this era because not everything was made super easy and super clear overall great game, i would recommend u buy it but u cant lmao have a great day

Rockstar and Take Two are really trying to beat Activision for the "worst game developer" award aren't they?

It's shocking they're making an *actual* remasters this time around instead of hastily porting over the mobile version(s) and calling it a day like they did for the PS3, Xbox 360 and their future consoles, but why couldn't they have kept the original GTA III/VC/SA games up on digital stores for the sake of nostalgia and preference for the original?

At least Bethesda kept the original version of Skyrim up when they released the special edition, albeit hidden from the store page and only accessible via link but it's *still* there.

One notable downside of the Steam version is that some songs were removed due to R* not wanting to renew their music licenses from record companies, and yes I firmly believe it's them being cheapskates because let's be real here, just how much have they made selling Sharkcards on GTA Online? That's what I thought.

If anyone still has GTA III/VC/SA installed in their Steam library, back that sh!t up on an external drive bucko. You'd especially wanna do this if you want to install that fix bugs/improve what Rockstar were too lazy to do themselves back when this was first ported over.

Good game(s) but damn, it really feels like Rockstar *wants* us to hate them.

Hace cinco años Carl Johnson huyó de los rigores de vivir en Los Santos, San Andreas... una ciudad asolada por las bandas, las drogas y la corrupción, en la que las estrellas de cine y los millonarios hacen lo posible por evitar a los traficantes y a los pandilleros.

Corren los 90 y Carl debe regresar. Su madre fue asesinada, su familia está destrozada y sus amigos de la infancia están al borde del abismo.

Al volver al barrio, un par de policías corruptos lo incriminan falsamente en un homicidio. CJ se ve arrastrado a un viaje que lo llevará a cruzar todo San Andreas para salvar a su familia y obtener el control de las calles.

I love this game so much. The graphics are beautiful (at least for the time), the story, and the character development is magnificent. You just have to try it for yourself, trust me. you won't regret buying this game and playing it how it's meant to be played or just having fun with mods or vanilla. Although this game has a lot of pros it also has some cons, because the game is almost 20 years old, and the Steam version is bad I would recommend you downgrading the version to 1.0 and installing some fixes like Widescreen Fix by ThirteenAG, SilentPatch by Silent, and GInput if you want to play on a controller (which I recommend. It will be useful in some missions), also the required thing to install, so that the mods above can actually work is Ultimate ASI Loader by ThirteenAG. My older brother played this game when I was a kid, and I wanted to play it so much. Now since I'm older I finally got my hands on it, and it is just like I remember it. If you made it this far, thank you for reading.

Fantastic game and still holds up today. Huge map, lots of things to do. Wacky characters and more pop culture references you can shake a stick at.

My only problem with this particular release is that Rockstar have done nothing to modernise the game and simply re-released the PC port from over 10 years ago. Make sure you lock the frame-rate, and take time out to properly bind controls as this game was a pre-XInput release. Mouse controls are a bit janky as there's no lock-on mechanism and the mouse seems to have 'steps' when aiming making it much harder than the controller. A few more options to prevent the model and texture pop-in would have been nice too.

Edit: Hoo boy, be careful what you wish for....

Awesome game in the old GTA universe. Lots of fun with missions and side activities. Some particular missions are way harder than others but when you get past these bumps it gets pretty easy. I'm not a fan of the gang war element of the game, but it is what it is. It took me 50 hours just to finish the main plotline and some side missions, and there's still plenty of stuff I haven't finished. Despite it being 2021 the graphics are somewhat acceptable to me at least. The game has a kind of "GTA 2" in 3D charm that newer GTA games don't have. You should have definitely bought it when it was available.

For those of you who have their nostalgia goggles on too tight, let me tell you how it is. This game blatantly rips off of Fallout: New Vegas. Characters throughout this franchise are blatant rip offs of Fallout NV's. Every hooker is just a prostitute from NV, every gangster is a ripoff of the legion, every cop is NCR. Not only that but they ripped off the M4, the shotguns, and the pistols. This game also blatantly rips the melee combat system in NV making this one of my least favorite titles out there. This game had the potentially to be something big, but found itself buried deep in my psyche as one of the worst rip offs of all time.

[b]2 Cents[/b] 

Who hasn't played this game yet? I don't know a soul who has owned a computer in the 2000's and not had AT LEAST one play through of GTA San Andreas. This was our introduction to PC Gaming and is still one of the most memorable games I've played so far. 


Even though the game came out in 2004, I still believe that it holds up against today's AAA games in terms of sheer content, gameplay value and mapping. It features three huge cities along with stretches of countryside - and I still remember driving from Los Santos to San Fierro listening to 50s country melodies on K Rose.

While the story may not seem have much of a direction, it is CJ's journey and the gameplay value it provides is incredible. The mission variety can go from protecting your hood from rival gangs and working for secret government agencies. And it doesn't hurt that there is a lot of side content you can do as well - ranging from driving a taxi to conquering neighborhoods for the Grove. 

If you are not really bothered by graphics (which can be enhanced using mods) and haven't finished through even one play through of this era defining masterpiece - drop whatever you are playing and do this first.

My cousin gave me a copy of gta sa at age 6. 
Best thing he could've ever done. 
Since my father didn't want me to play violent video games I always had to be careful. 
at the time I didn't care about the violent and crime aspects of the game at all. I spent thousands of hours just driving around, enjoying the open world & modding the game with new cars. 

Later in the 2010s I began hosting a private MTA server with my bro [url=http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198396581059]LSB[/url]. We had crazy amounts of fun with it throughout the years with tons of server plugins, car mods, handling editors, ect. 
The edited video footage I uploaded to YouTube at the time covers 700 hours of private server playtime alone. 
We had tons of fun, it's incredible. 

Now I 2021 after Rockstar decided to delist this game for their 'amazing' "definitive edition" I decided to reexperience this gem with all the classic features the 1.0 downgraded version offers.
I gotta Say, it's still great and tons of fun. really sad they decided to take it down but hey, at least I have it... :/

Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas is a to put it in the least of words, a fun ride. It has great likeable characters, an influential set of antagonists, some of whom are unexpected, an interesting story which is not trying to be the most realistic but iconic, some of the most memorable lines of dialogue of the entire GTA series and a decent soundtrack.

You play as Carl Johnson, a young black adult, who is forced to return to a life of gangs, drive-bys and corrupt cops in the city of Los Santos after his mother is accidentally killed in a drive-by shooting by a rival gang, originally meant for his older brother, Sweet. The story takes the protagonist on an expansive tale of adventure, alliances, betrayals, revenge, and poetic justice across cities, the countryside, deserts among other farthest reaches of the state of San Andreas.

The controls, considering how old this game is, seems pretty archaic at times. However, it is not a herculean job to adapt to the control scheme. Besides that, this game has a lot to do, and would probably take you hours to explore anything. Among the most touted features of the game are the ability to customise how the player looks in general and how the world interacts with him by eating, exercising at the gym, trying on different clothing, footwear and accessories and not to mention, haircuit. Further, the game lets you traverse the map on road, water, and in air. The vehicle selection in this game in gianarmous, including utility vehicles with functional add-ons. 

I'd recommend this game 100%.

Easily the best entry of the classic GTA trilogy, Grand Theft Auto V has its roots in San Andreas which expanded its already excellent open world formula to create a truly epic sandbox with some of the best missions and dynamic systems in open world games for its time. With numerous locations, light RPG progression and an excellent campaign and side missions, San Andreas remains one of Rockstar's many masterpieces.
